151341452.review: I've been playing video games since I was 8 years old, I've played hundreds of games across so many genres and consoles. I've played a lot of visual novels, I usually prefer my games to have some sort of fantasy setting as opposed to just contemporary modern life. Which is why it took me a while to give this game a go. It was sitting in my wish-list for months as I saw it was recommended as similar to other games I loved, but I'll admit I was doubtful that I would enjoy this free game where you play as a regular person with no fantasy twist or turns. Well, dozens of play-throughs and tears later I have never been so happy to be wrong. This game is like a comforting hug that I didn't know I needed. It is hard to explain how incredible this game is. I've never experienced a game before where it felt like the game itself just wanted you to be happy and to feel heard. Our Life: Beginnings & Always now sits firmly as my No.1 favorite game I've ever played.

I don't know where to even begin. The writing is wholesome to the point of making you yearn for a childhood you did not even have. The art is adorable and draws you in making you love each character. This story gives you not only intimacy in romance if you so choose to romance a character.  (which honestly they are all so amazing and every moment is worth playing)
The game Our life doesn't just focus on romance but also
Emotional intimacy, Intellectual Intimacy, Spiritual Intimacy, Creative Intimacy, and last but not least Family.
When parents accept, love, and show affection to their children, even when they make mistakes or fall short of expectations this game provides a warm and caring family.
Our life: Beginnings and always is like playing a game that has pieces of your soul that call you home waiting to comfort you when you need it.

I hope this review helps and that more people play this particular story.

149957736.review: One of the best games I've played, would recommend it to anyone! The characters are all so loveable, not just the main love interest, but the MC's family and other friends too. Unlike a lot of other otome-style games I've played, in this game there are no "wrong" choices, but they do impact the story and paths of your character in meaningful ways. MC's appearance, gender, sexuality, personality, skin-tone are all customizable but it's not a throwaway thing where it has no bearing on the game. Like if your character wears a lot of accessories, it might be something other characters comment on (as an example). They are also things that can change as the player grows up and develops more. Such a unique and refreshing game and you can tell it was written and made with so much love. Looking forward to GB's next game which was successfully funded on Kickstarter recently.

149884515.review:
HOOOOOO my god. so many good things I could say about this game. This is also the first time I've felt moved enough to post a review about something. First of all: if you're an I Was A Teenage Exocolonist fan you're going to LOVE this. That game is a huge comfort game to me and this one is definitely going into that list after this. It's so nice. The vibes? Immaculate? The story? Amazing.

I think ultimately my favorite part of this game is the fact that you're character is just. Allowed to not be okay? You don't get to see that a lot in dating sims, even in Exocolonist. Like you're always comforting the Love Interest but never getting anything back from them. You're allowed to be insecure about stuff, to get upset when bad things happen, you're allowed to feel however you want and the Love Interest and supporting characters are there for you if you've been there for them. I know it's a silly thing to be happy about and to enjoy but as someone who's been having a rough go of it recently its just wonderful to see something like this implemented. It's all so realistic and human to me, and captures it all really well. It's grounded and amazing.

Frankly enough there's enough content in this game that I think it deserves to be a paid game, but I love the fact that there is so much in this free dating sim, and that you have the option to add more if you want to. You can definitely get a full experience without purchasing the DLC. I'm planning on buying the step 1-3 dlc's once I get my paycheck since I already bought the wedding DLC and that was AMAZING as well. I definitely reccommend supporting the creators by purchasing the DLC or on their Patreon.

148646117.review:
It's so sweet and comforting I cried. It makes me so happy while playing it and so lonely after it was over. The writer of Our Life writes story lines and characters in a way that makes me feel seen. It gives me hope that there are kind people out there that are worth getting to know and who are understanding of the way I am. The game also made me reflect more about myself and motivate me to be a better person. I would love to have such positive bonds with others in real life the way the characters do in the game and to do so I must do the best I can to better myself so I can find and forge these types of relationships. This game inspires me to work harder to make my little piece in the world better. 

(Also can you tell I just finished Baxter's route and felt so sentimental I wrote this post because his issues, fears, and ways of handling his problems are scarily identical to mine? The route gave me enough hope to motivate me to start making some changes to my life so I can reach for what makes me happy too.)

I'm so grateful to the creator and everyone who worked on this game for their hard work and courage in putting their work out there for others to see. I've always felt it takes some serious determination and bravery to put your art out there where others can judge it. But I think they did an amazing job and I wish them luck in their future endeavors! So thank you for creating this game! It's my favorite!

On that note - yes, I do recommend this game! The base game is free so what do you have to lose by trying it out? I definitely recommend the dlcs too if you end up liking the game! (Note: Cove is the love interest in the base game, you'll need to get the dlcs for Derek's and Baxter's routes.)

148602277.review:
i stayed up for 28 hours straight because i was determined to play this game in mostly one sitting, i did not want to sleep. i was not tired, it kept my interest until nearly the end. the game took 16 hours to finish it made me cry i cried over this game i don't cry over games it rewired my brain i haven't been the same since that fateful tuesday. i can't stop thinking about it. every day this game pulls me from whatever task i intend to complete and i am distracted, i am looking at our life, i am thinking about our life, i am playing our life, i am plagued with the entire game looping start to finish in my brain. it haunts me and i appreciate it. this game has absolutely decimated my brain and i am thankful. i react so very viscerally each time i hear the end credits song play from spotify or each time i see the loading screen, it is out of love.

on the positive, holy SHIT the options are awesome- they're extensive, and while kind of useless it makes the player character feel like YOU!! dialogue changes to match how you feel towards cove even if its as little as wording things a little awkwardly. you can shape your experience and its WONDERFUL
i LOVE romance as a genre- i am a WHOLE LESBIAN but the story-line of falling in love with cove and playing it out in my head with the "my feelings for cove" screen helping out- it's so fun!! and you do not even NEED to make it a romance, it can be a story of indifference towards your neighbor or it can be a story of simple friendship.
story wise, while simple, it's so pleasant. it's comfortable, and happy. it's not like EVERYTHING's perfect, everyone has their issues like cove and his family or even your own- it's a happy game but it's not mary sue levels of joy. it's nice. it's comfortable
it has enough content for me to get nearly another 10 hours of gameplay in just replaying and seeing what different opinions and choices do, and i haven't even seen all of it yet!!
The concept is crazy interesting to me as well- seeing how the characters grow and change over the years is wonderful
A personal thing, i absolutely fucking LOVE summer, romance, and this game sort of covers struggles i have around growing up, and being scared of it. I love feel-good stuff, too, so this game feels absolutely Made for me

on the negative side, some of the options i personally felt uncomfortable answering- the body type related questions in the middle of the story- it doesn't come up in the story as far as i know and i would've much preferred a skip option, but the question comes up Twice and is brief, it's a preference thing. there's also no gender option- you can choose your pronouns and the game assumes your gender based on that alone, which is a little rough.
preference wise, it's simple, overall without drama, and is a pretty long game! like i said, roughly 16 hours! it's definitely not everyone's thing!! 

finishing up, i absolutely recommend this game. the grip it has on me is fucking wild, if it seems like something you'd like i ABSOLUTELY suggest you play it. i can't wait for the next one, it'll be even better :)) 
this review is a super silly tone- the first half is, at least, but i do wholeheartedly recommend the game- the pros and cons are fr! i could go on and on about how much i adore this game- i LITERALLY DID this is a LONG ASS REVIEW 💀

However, when my friend mentioned about Our Life: Beginnings & Always, I was immediately interested and I was HOOKED. The choices and customization is something I haven't seen for a game that's completely free besides DLCs. I don't think I can play any other visual novel dating sim the same way again. Our Life is my favorite Visual novel of all time.

Cove Holden is one of the best dating sim characters ever- though the fact that you can treat this game as a friend sim instead and still have a deep platonic love is testament to it's quality. I could gush for hours about how happy playing this games makes me, how much I love the characters, how much I love Cove or even my deep admiration and awe for the team that managed to put such an intricate and unique vn together. But I have a character limit here so I am just gonna say- if you like Visual novels and slice of life storylines, give our life a chance. It's free- though the paid dlcs are 100% worth it in my opinion- the experience isnt any less impactful without them and the base game provides a lovely experience all on it's own with hours worth of content. I look forward to it's sequel and other future games by this creator.

147909845.review: This is an amazing read with no real reason to skip over because it's free. I was drawn to the overt queerness and the way the story handles gendering the MC, and although initially Cove didn't look like my type, mine ended up being a total jock Golden and I'm all about it. I will say, it does feel like the "main character" is actually the bittersweet sensations that come with growing older and entering new phases of our lives, of moving on, of fond moments becoming fond memories, and of watching your old haunts becoming suddenly smaller. Each phase of life in the game (there are 4) ends on a sentimental note encapsulating these emotions, making the story you just read feel both fleeting and ephemeral, sort of begging the reader to want to cling onto everything as they progress. The characters are compelling and distinct enough, but truly the crux of emotion comes from those kinds of concepts, and the romance thrives on top of that foundation.

147705466.review:
In all honesty, there's almost nothing I dislike about this game.

The story was relaxing and funny, with lots of wholesome moments between Cove and the player, and it kept me interested almost all the way through the game. There were so many different ways to customize the player and the world around them, and the soundtrack - although a little repetitive - was fantastic.

The only thing I didn't enjoy was how drawn-out the ending felt. It was super long, and sixty percent of it was the same "I love my life" message said a thousand different ways. I found myself exiting out of the game a lot more frequently during that part, and losing focus for long enough that I'd miss part of what the characters were saying when it got back to the actual story.

But, all in all, it was a masterpiece of a game and a well-written story that I enjoyed a lot. The voice acting was amazing, the dialogue felt natural and realistic, and the characters had their own, well-thought-out personalities and personal lives.

I 100% recommend this game, it's truly amazing!

147548859.review:
I usually don't write reviews on games, but Our Life has touched my heart like no other game has. I found Our Life at a very rough time in my life. Playing it brought me comfort and an escape. It made me attached in a way where I wasn't obsessive like other visual novels usually encourage.
Recently I replayed and it's timeless. I wish I could experience this game for the first time again.
The relationships and memories you make in this visual novel made me laugh, cry, and blush. TL;DR: EMOTIONAL!!!
It gives you so many options and there are so many ways to interact with the main interest. I promise you won't be bored because it has something for everyone. Plus it isn't over-ally sexual which is hard to find with visual novels. 
The characters are beautifully written. There's diversity but it doesn't feel forced or over-explained for the sake of being unique. The family dynamics gave me the comfort that I've longed for in games. I liked that they weren't afraid, to be honest and talk about how they felt about the other's actions. Cove was the best companion anyone could ask for. His backstory was masterfully crafted without being over the top. Plus he's a cutie! 
The visuals and soundtrack are to die for. The music sets the tone for the various situations you get into. The special moment visuals will forever be ingrained in my head. The backgrounds give so much personality to the small CA town that the game is set in. You can tell there was a ton of love put into this project. 
I've never seen a game so charming while tackling so many topics in such a graceful manner that will remain with me for years to come. If you are reading this and considering downloading, take the plunge. It's worth it. 

In short, this is a beautiful game that I wholly recommend to anyone willing to take the plunge and try it out. <3

147250315.review:
While I have some constructive critiques for the game, I want to start by saying this game is wholesome AF. So sweet you will get diabetes by the end of the second chapter. I normally dislike the "boy next door" trope for an otome because it starts off when you're adults and it's a cheap way to force emotional investment by assuming the past between characters- but this game actually starts off in younger years so you can have the cute meet and form a history with one another. It's an earned attachment, rather than a told one. And the early stages keep things innocent and clean; no weird stuff with kids like some negative reviews insinuate. Those phases are adorable world building with the friends/family, not relationship stuff.

All the customization is awesome for those who want choice in how your character is presented and what sort of play through you're wanting. It felt weird to try having a crush start before they hit young adults, and I think letting them just be relaxed friends for the first two stages worked awesome for building a rapport with one another and helping each other pursue interests. I've seen different comments about how Cove can turn out, and in my playthrough he steadily developed into a semi-introverted to the larger world but self-assured and happy man who was openly affectionate and supportive of his close circle of friends and girlfriend. A massive growth arc that was sweet to see. Ends with them having a place together, and a home full of pets they couldn't have as kids; they own a business together (I head canon their "hospitality" business is them having an oceanside B&B their parents helped them navigate opening that's not far from their home town) while doing nature conservation stuff in their free time because they both love the ocean they grew up with. Very cute "doing the adulting thing" for these two and their interests. 

I was rooting for Miranda and Terry to be a thing in stage 3, and cheered when they stuck around and it happened in stage 4, instead of them quietly dipping out and never heard from again like some other characters were. Those two were also cute AF and made a sweet couple. Relationships in general are depicted in healthy and sweet ways- from the moms in their long-lasting marriage to Cole's parents getting their much needed divorce and becoming much better people and co-parents who can now chill out with one another for weeks on end and act like a real family during that time. Derek was a sweetheart of a kid and I was glad to see him make a return in the fourth chapter and rocking his glow up and great life. I can see why he eventually got an option in a DLC to be an alt love interest to Cove. The other guy in stage 3, though, blew in like a hurricane of sleaze and felt so shoehorned into the story. He screams try hard, bad news f*ck boy. It was easy to ignore him and continue on with the day/stage; and I kinda wish you could later  have an option to convince your friends to not get in his car and/or go off with him, but my attempts to find that option failed to make it happen. *shrug* Is what it is, I guess. Some people obviously liked him, to get his own DLC eventually, but he wasn't my cup of tea.

I also appreciate how, most of the time, the game acknowledges various little choices in earlier stages. Or, if you do "moments" outside the sequential order presented on the menu, later choices will still sometimes acknowledge events of the previous moments that just happened- like relationship status changing or that a memorable thing happened in the little story. There's also a nice attention to detail by changing up sprites for each stage, having clothes or hairstyles altered even for the parents who don't have the more drastic growth/aging differences to account for. 

The main critiques- I only played the main game, haven't gotten the DLCs at the time of the review. I don't know what the DLCs contain for content. But I was somewhat confused by some things in later stages- such as the parents teasing Cove for being a "trouble maker"... When he literally never did anything I'd consider "trouble"? He's a super well behaved kid, even once he opens up more. Unless you consider completely innocent snuggle sleep in an RV loft for a roadtrip "trouble"? If so, that's a stretch for all the teasing he gets. Maybe that was written because of stuff in DLCs they knew would be later coming and perhaps show another facet of Cove? I don't know because I don't have the DLC, but as this was a direct playthrough of the main game, it seemed out of place.

Also, as kids, Cove and friends would wander the town, go do little treat shopping on the main drag, etc. Parents never seemed bothered by it because it's a small town and they're not leaving it. But then, suddenly, in stage 3 the parents took on weird tones of helicopter parents who were simultaneously infantilizing these 18ish year old kids who are done high school and already semi-independent. Getting all up in their business and pushing for more family moments than in previous chapters, rather than letting them do their own things; and pulling a weird stunt at the farmer's market to "push" the couple into splitting off for the morning, and finding out what it's like to shop on their own without parents around. Huh??? It's a really weird trait/event from all the parents given the previously established dynamics. Why would the grown teens have an issue with it? Do the devs forget that teens, especially legally adult teens, LIKE their independence and usually know how to do those basic things already? Things THESE young adults had already been kinda doing since childhood? Why treat them like they've never so much as left their backyard all of a sudden? And if your character shrugs it off and isn't bothered, like the grown adult she is, then COVE will get upset on your behalf for your mothers orchestrating you being "abandoned" without warning in the market and say you're just too nice to express how messed up that was to your own moms. What?! No, my character was happy to get away from the suddenly odd acting moms to do her thing and browse with her kinda-almost-boyfriend for tasty treats and produce. No upset what so ever was ever expressed/thought/felt. That "moment" was just so weird to include and force into happening.

Also, there seems to be some small bugs with the game logging different choices, or maybe the devs not fully accounting for some choices. This was a blind playthrough, no foreknowledge of plot going in. So I had my character not take the $20 from Mr Holden at the very beginning because he seemed like an odd man and you shouldn't take money from strangers, but she agreed to meet his son if her moms said okay to her playing with the supposed new neighbor's son. The money is a non-issue and her hanging out with Cove was her own choice after meeting him and thinking he was a nice, if sad, kid who needed a friend. But then, for the rest of the game, every stage had moments of bringing up the initial $20 incident, acting like it was this big secret that might upset Cove because my character had been initially bribed to be his friend, and asking all the way up to stage four if I wanted to finally tell him. And I kept saying no, it wasn't something worth bringing up. because she was NOT bribed to be his friend at first. And that choice kept not being acknowledged and the game REALLY tries hard to make you feel guilty/force some drama to happen on that non-issue if you made that choice. Big oversight on the devs when it comes to that choice that was a little annoying to continually see pop up. 

(Continued in Comments, I have a lot of feedback, sorry)

147030530.review:
This game is an experience, one I recommend anyone to play. I played it first on Itch.io and then moved to the steam version when I found out it was there too. I bought all the DLC's and enjoyed every part of it thoroughly.

Even after playing through it numerous times I am still struck by scenes that aim for your emotions, regardless of whether I've seen them before or not. It is a game that just so wholesome and nice at times that you can't help but smile as you play it, not many games do that to me. I like a majority of the characters, the setting and the general pacing of the entire thing.

The only complaints that come to mind are the fact it ends and there's so few moments to explore for each step, but that's just because I desire more of it xD It does have a limiting factor in that it is [i]always[/i] and you never get to see life outside of the summer holidays, such as seeing everyone go to school, anyone else's birthday outside of one character or any other events that would happen outside of it. A real shame but the sequel seems to be aiming towards fixing that. I do wish the MC's portrait was used more as you can spend a lot of time creating it only for it to never show up during gameplay, which again the sequel fixes.

I really enjoyed this game and if you have an inkling to play it I say go for it, you'll enjoy your time in Sunset Bird :D

Overall Score: 8/10

146577268.review:
i HIGHLY recommend this game, one of the best romance visual novels ive ever played, hands down. the fact you have SO much control over your character and how much that affects the game is amazing. i've done two playthroughs at this point, one relaxed but kind of direct romance with cove where i had a crush on him and confessed as soon as i could and one where i played a shy sensitive girl who cried at the first sign of danger, and i was actually shocked at how differently the routes were and how different cove was at certain points. 
for example, in the first route, i stood up for cove at every opportunity and didn't let anyone badmouth him in my presence, and he stayed pretty reserved as a result, content to let me defend him. alternatively, in my second playthrough, anytime someone so much as teased me, i would cry and it was cove who leapt to my defense, and he became more outgoing as a result, i even let him confess his love instead of the other way around. it took him longer but my god it was SOO cute as a result, there were multiple entirely new scenes in moments i had gone through in the past as a result of making different choices and playing a character who had a different personality. 
the game remembers even the littlest choices you make, whether you are a morning person, short, tall, a hard studier, shy, brave, whatever. i kept finding myself going 'it remembered THAT?' it is incredibly immersive honestly. my one complaint is that i wish we got to see a picture of our character and cove together, i think that would be so cute, but i understand why they havent done that. 

overall, amazing romance game, made me cry so many times. i would die for cove holden, and honestly i would kill for him too. try it out, its free after all.

145828712.review:
To be short about it this game is absolutely amazing. It immerses you into it's world and before you know it you've been playing for hours. What I love most about the game is it made me feel like I was a child again, it made me feel alive and that I could do anything. As someone who had to mature fast in life to help support my family this game gave me the chance to feel something that I thought was gone for good to the point I've honestly been scared to finish the game a second time and move forward.

So while there is no real Sunset Bird, Cove Holden and the gang it taught me to love myself and my image which I'm so grateful for. There is a great inclusion of anyone identifying as LGBTQIA+ or straight and platonic/romantic options to choose from. GB Patch games definitely went all out with the options as there are so many choices. When I replayed it it still took me back to a happier time just as much as the first time I played.

Our Life has made me want to be able to become a great parent to be able to provide my kids with the life depicted in this game as best I can. I know how ridiculous this sounds but I really can't put into words the games impact on me and how much it's helped me grow as a person. So tonight I am going to finish the game and I won't let my fear of moving on stop me because I can proudly say I love myself now, and I hope if you're reading this you love yourself just as much.

145337503.review:
This game is absolutely amazing!!!

I knew I needed to play it as soon as I stumbled on it because it looked great. It was even better than I imagined. I fell in love with the characters and all aspects of the game instantly. I played it once a week on stream and it was legitimately the highlight of my week.

If you are looking for a game with representation of a bunch of different types of people in natural, ordinary situations and relationships, definitely check this game out. It has trans, gay, straight, demisexual, autistic, neurotypical, neurodivergent, married, divorced, dating, adopted, introverted, extroverted, etc. They fit so many different types of people in without it feeling forced or unnatural which is awesome.

And the player character/story options are incredibly customizable. From appearance to sexuality and gender identity to how you feel about your body to how interested or not you are into romance and physical affection. You truly can customize the experience to be how you want.

The story is amazing. It's so pure and real and doesn't feel forced or unnatural. It's not shallow either but deals with some deep emotions and struggles in an honest and uplifting way.

I just can't say enough how much I adore this game! <3

145310571.review:
As a writter myself and a person who reads A LOT. And when i mean A LOT ... Its A LOT ! Not even kidding.

I can say this visual novel use everything perfectly, stereotypes, the set-ups, the scenes, its like everything is perfectly hand-crafted to hit exactly where it needs to. You can try to close yourself, that wont work. It'll hit you, as hard as life.

Not too much, not too less. It's like a perfectly refined needle who's only job is to pierce through your heart.

I'm pretty tough in terms of mental stability, i can handle most things without much difficulties, but sometimes, its just too well done and thats exactly what i was searching and what i needed.

This game have the perfect title : Its Life. Everything in the actual life of a young boy and teenage boy is here, the fears, the discoveries, the fun parts, family, love, etc ...

At the same time, i say to yourself "They have a beautiful life"

What is mine in comparrison ? And that's what hit the hardest ! In the actual society, nobody will probably be able to have this kind of life, todays kids, todays parents, it is just not possible. And that just forces you to face it : This actual world is very grim. Our society is grim, what went wrong ? 

How can we be in this state while i'm sure, everyone wanna have the kind of life your character and Cove are having ? I went for the default name Jamie, wich is enough for me (He's not me, just a character, i'm not much relating to it much).

145234746.review:
Our Life: Beginnings & Always has been the surprise hit of my year. I picked it up for free on a whim one day, and now... I think my play time speaks for itself.

This also happens to be one of the most difficult games to review because of how much it and the characters have come to mean to me. As a young man who has recently been coming to terms with his sexuality, I found some much-needed catharsis in Our Life. The art is gorgeous, the music is surprisingly moving, and the writing is sweet in its simplicity. But most importantly, it allowed me to reclaim some of the fun, scary, touching, difficult, exciting, and even mundane moments that I missed out on while growing up: The moments that bring about discussions of life and love and happiness and purpose and future. The moments of silence where a hug or a kiss speaks volumes all on its own.

I'm not afraid to admit that this game had me in tears, multiple times. The nostalgia that comes with passing time is used to maximum effect. It was so special to see my MC grow up, develop a crush, and then fall in love with Cove. When you step into the world of Our Life, every insecurity melts away with the support of your neighbors, your sister, your two moms, and a very caring (boy)friend. Sunset Bird is the perfect place to escape, if only for a little while.

The amount of content you get from this free visual novel is unreal. It's fully complete and playable without having to spend a cent. If you're still on the fence, you have absolutely nothing to lose by trying. But if (like me) you can't get enough of our lovable seafoam-green cinnamon roll with a heart of gold, Cove James Holden, the DLCs add hours upon hours of content for dirt cheap. I've bought every DLC to date, and I can honestly say that they are far and away the best Steam purchases I've ever made.

This game has given me some wonderful memories. But my time isn't over. I have a feeling I'll be coming home to visit Sunset Bird often.

11/10 HIGHLY recommended!

TL;DR
Amazing love interest and good art. If you are a fan of dating sims/visual novels PLEASE get this game, it's free.

On a warm july day I was like "Hey, this is a free visual novel, I'll play it for a bit and probably not finish it, but who cares" and proceeded to finish the game the same day. No joke, this is the best visual novel I've EVER played. I think I've seen all the content the game has to offer and I still want to play more. 

Cove is one of my favorite characters ever. Throughout the entire game he got me giggling and kicking my feet, it's actually crazy how much I was crushing on him. he's never too annoying or repetitive like other love interests in visual novels. He's like an actual person with thoughts and feelings and not just a husk of a character. It was a nice change of pace being able to grow up with Cove and learn about him that way instead of him just listing off everything that happened to him in his life. it made finally getting together with him so much more impactful and rewarding because you two grew up together and know eachother on a personal level. Even now after all this time played, I can't get enough of him and how well he's written.

The sprites and artwork are really well made and nice to look at, but sometimes it can be a little goofy. (Step 1 firefly catching, 8 year old Cove has a full sized adult hand LOL, and Step 3 "Late shift" with the overly anime styled Cove)

I would write more but that would go into spoilers and I would not want to spoil this game for anyone. If you are on the fence on playing this game PLEASE DO. It's free, at worst you wont like it, at best you'll have an amazing time.

(But ignore everything I said about Cove because Derek is just the best)

i did not think i was going to fall in love with Our Life: Beginnings & Always as much as i did. the characters, story, art, and music all come together to create such a beautiful and heartwarming novel. i love the concept of being able to grow up alongside the cast, it really immerses you into the cozy town of sunset bird. the customization features are also incredible. you can grow and change who you are as a person just like in real life. i love the fact that you aren't "forced" into doing anything, unlike other "choose your own story" visual novels. you're free to choose how your relationships are with other people, how your relationship is with yourself, and other physical and personality defining things. this story gives me the ability to live a childhood i never had, as whoever i want to be, and i thank the developers for creating this masterpiece. i cannot express just how much i adore this game in this one review, so i will leave it at that. 

please, if you're unsure about the game, just give it a shot. we are blessed to be able to have this amazing game for free. there is hours of content on just the base game alone. (though i totally recommend getting the dlc's if you can)
thank you gb patch games for making this heartwarming, adventure filled story, and i'm looking forward to the next installment coming soon :)

144568558.review:
tl;dr - im in love . i adore everyone . xx

notices:
- i'm writing this review after playing all of the DLC, and i will be leaving individual reviews on all of the DLC
- i have yet to play all the platonic endings
- i have a ton of hours in this game, but despite this there is still so much more new dialogue to unlock

okay, so moving on to my actual review, which will mostly be me appreciating all the details in this game.

this VN has 4 steps, and takes you from childhood to adulthood. i loved how customisable this VN is, you could change your pronouns after each step, you can change how you look, and how cove looks (to a certain degree). the amount of customisation in this game makes me surprised that it's even free? just wow.

i would like to spend a moment just considering how well written this VN is. i didn't notice any spelling or grammar problems, and i found the whole flow of the game to be natural. all the characters felt like real people, and they all had their own unique personalities; i had to highlight this as some VNs have characters that all feel the same.

this VN covers several serious topics in both a lighthearted and serious manner, depending on how you approach the topics. some of the topics include [spoiler]divorced parents, shared custody/visitations to both parents, body dysmorphia, insecurities, and many more topics,[/spoiler] which i think is lovely as they're all naturally included. they are all indeed common and normal aspects of life.

overall, i can't get enough of this VN !!! it is so worth it, even without the DLC, because for me it was still over 24 hours of gameplay. i loved all the art, it's so cute, gorgeous, and amazing. so much representation, like, i was not surprised & was so pleased when i found out that [spoiler]cove is autistic, LIKE IT JUST MAKES SENSE,[/spoiler] and i was super happy to see the representation as he is one of the main characters. there is also poc, and lgbt+ representation numerous times. such a lovely and nostalgic game, so cute.

144442965.review:
I first heard of this game through TikTok. I kept telling myself "I'll play it one of these days, it seems cute", but life got busy and I kept putting it off. Eventually, as I was scrolling through Steam, I saw Our Life in my recommended games. I was pretty board that day, so I thought "I'll just play it for an hour", then suddenly, 6 hours passed and I was hooked. 

Our Life is unlike any dating sim I have ever played. It made me feel real emotions, from sadness and anger, to love and admiration. My character felt like an extension of myself, and the response options felt like real responses I would give IRL. 

I genuinely felt loved and cared about by the characters just for being myself, unlike other dating sims where I would have to follow a guide in order to make a certain character love me. That's the added benefit of this game not having any bad endings, you get to choose whichever options you want, and you won't get penalized for it.

Overall, I am so glad I discovered this game, because I truly feel like it has changed me in ways I can't describe, and for that I couldn't be more grateful. This game now holds a very special place in my heart, and you better believe I'll be buying all of the DLC and playing multiple playthroughs in the future.

If you're even slightly interested in this game, please check it out. For the price of FREE, it's pretty worth it :)

144387650.review: My advice to the interested: give this game a chance. I came into this game with a LOT of preconceived suspicions. The game being free made me wonder about its quality. I wasn't particularly keen on deuteragonist and main-man Cove's green hair. I wasn't sure what to think about a "dating sim" that spent two-thirds of its time on the subject of children... And I was pleasantly proven wrong, over and over again. This game is of the highest quality, from the breathtaking artwork to the groovy, unforgettable soundtrack. I fell in love with Cove's personality, his unique look and gorgeous aesthetic, the cast of quirky and very relatable supporting characters... I won't lie that towards the end, I found myself reading along with a growing lump in my throat, truthfully emotionally invested in the story. I was preparing for a bittersweet, even crushing ending, and instead of my story ending with a bang or a whimper, it ended on a soft, sweet, murmuring sigh that brought back long-forgotten memories of a life I once lived - long ago. I received the product for free, now I'm typing this review after willing forking out the money to get the add-on content. Our Life: Beginnings & Always deserves every penny; it was and is a worthy purchase.

144137738.review:
I usually never write reviews for Steam games; I like to be reclusive and enjoy from a distance. But GB Patch has practically stolen my heart with this Visual Novel.

As shown with my hours at the time of this review, I enjoy this... A LOT. Cove Holden has been a sincere effect on my life that I can't ultimately shake. He's there every time you need him.

I always resort to OL: B&A when I'm in a rut, be it depressive, anxious, or just when I need some creative inspiration, because this man with seafoam green hair practically boosts my mood in any way possible. And let me tell you when I say I'm now envious of the world GB has created, as even my own comfort characters cannot exercise enough TLC to help me through trying times.

The artwork is amazing, the storyline is lax. Nothing is ever rushed. It makes you feel like you're living through it in real time, and gives you a way to express whatever your MC wants to go through. I swear the amount of times I've paused on sentimental moments with Cove's adorable yet warm expressions and just letting it soak in has never better fixed my self-esteem. Although better to hear it from someone in real life, Cove gives me that start.

In relation, to support the endeavors of such a great VN, I've had ALL the DLCs (even including the soundtrack, which is such a nice vibe to listen to when moments get stressful; they convey such great emotion that really sets in the story's mood alongside keeping it calm enough for players to not get sent into angst spiral) and have enjoyed each and every aspect of them as well. There is literally no fault in this. If anything, it made me aware of my own faults, which made me burst into tears of roughly 5 hours of the 200 at review. May not be much, but damn those tears ran hard. [spoiler]Especially during Step 3's epilogue in the car. My god that has me crying EVERY. SINGLE. TIME.[/spoiler]

I started this journey with Cove roughly a year and a half ago, and I don't regret my decision one bit. This gave me a rebirth of my childhood and what I didn't experience, made me remember all the goofy times I'd awkwardly crush on my friends in my teenage years, and reminds me that life is everchanging as an adult with outcomes fluctuating so heavily and slowly that all we can really say it that tomorrow's going to be better.

To those reading this, although Cove may do it better than I: [b] You are valid, you are loved, you are you. [/b] Don't let the world change who you are just because it's not the norm. Show that uniqueness and who you are are what makes the world go round, what keeps us on that everchanging flow. Sadness, guilt, and regret are only temporary, and that all will be better if you make the effort. [i] Love yourself, simple as that. [/i]

1,000% would recommend this.

143536318.review:
At this point, I doubt 'Our Life: Beginnings & Always' really needs many words. It has become a big name that most visual novel players already know of, but why not leave some praise where it's due!

Our Life is extremely lovely and rewarding to play. No matter how many times you play it, there's probably still a choice that you haven't tried out yet. It's wide variety of choices - choices that truly do matter - make for an interesting character progression and leave this game as somewhat of a novelty in it's genre. So far, I haven't played any other visual novels that feel as personal and player determined as this one. 

The characters are all extremely lovable and sweet - starting from grumpy Jeremy and ending with the worlds-best-dad Cliff. They're all well fleshed out and you get the feeling that they all come with their own stories and histories that influence who they are now. 

Allowing the player to pick and choose with stories they want to play in which order is incredible and definitely something I haven't seen before. It makes each playthrough feel refreshed and adds a nice shot of variability. 

All in all, Our Life: Beginnings & Always is truly one of it's kind.

143343448.review:
I honestly did not expect the roller-coaster of emotions and experiences this single game would take me through. I picked it up because it looked cute and I liked the concept from the short summary I read, and it was free, so why not? I basically binged my way through the game for like 5 days straight before reaching the end, and every single second of it was amazing. The characters are all very unique and have depth, and they grow and change over the course of the story. They all felt very real, and it definitely was not hard to fall in love with each of them. On top of that, the story also contained completely custom (and very well-made) soundtracks, character CGs, backgrounds, and sprites, and it showed that the entire story & dialogue were well-thought out and overall amazing. 
The experience was very unique as well, I've never seen anything like it. There is a wide variety of choices and customization options you can make, including the main character's race, gender, sexuality / romantic orientation, personality, interests, body type, preferences, and, to a degree, relationships. You can progress the romantic side of the story at your own pace, and, on top of that, the game won't force you to even date or show romantic interest in the main love interest; you can simply choose to stay friends with him the entire game if you'd rather. If all of that wasn't already enough, the choices you make actually do matter in this game, unlike many others I've seen of the same genre/style. It isn't very easy to predict how exactly your choices will influence the main love interest and your experiences with him, too. It's sort of a giant guessing game, but it was worth every second of it. If I'm being honest, the closer I got to the end of the game, the more bittersweet it felt. Despite having completely different experiences than the MC, the game still managed to get across a very nostalgic feel, making me both mourn and cherish a childhood that I never lived. I definitely cried more than once near the end. Aside from that, the game even had a sort of restorative/healing aspect to it; I feel way more at ease/reassured after playing through the game than I did before starting it up for the first time. As soon as I'm able, I'm hoping I can go back and replay the game to try and discover all the other experiences I missed that it has to offer.
Needless to say I've already bought all of the DLCs, because it is actually criminal for this to be a free game. I haven't had a chance to try all of them yet, as I'd rather savor them than binge through it again, but I already know I won't regret it; the ones I've gotten to experience so far are further proof of that. If you still aren't sure, please, at least try the game out! It is an absolute masterpiece that I wish never had to end, but alas. <3
I will most definitely be following along with the development of Our Life: Now & Forever (aka OL2), as well!!

143233625.review:
I started this visual novel not expecting a lot, but after finishing it, I was blown away. This is in many ways a masterpiece. It is more than just a dating sim. It is an exploration of various types of life relationships and choices. I recommend it not only to anyone who enjoys romance, but also the slice of life genre in general. It follows the journey of the MC (you) and the male lead from being 8 year olds to adults that have moved out of your parents' homes.

Pros:
- It is diverse in its inclusion of various races, body types, genders, and sexualities. MC can chose he, she, or they pronouns. The male lead is pan and demisexual.
- Different family dynamics are explored. MC has two moms and the male lead's parents are separated. MC and their sister are adopted.
- The novel doesn't only focus on the male lead. The MC also spends time with friends, siblings,  parents, and their cousin. 
- MC doesn't actually need to be romantically involved with the male lead. They can choose to just stay friends throughout the novel and nothing more.
- The novel portrays the bittersweet experience of growing up beautifully. I cried quite a few times. 

Cons:
- I know it's free and I can't really complain, but I do wish there was just a little bit more art for some of the unique scenes. A lot of the art is reused. SPOILERS AHEAD. For example, there is a scene where the MC, Cove, Terry, and Miranda are eating out together. I would have loved a little illustration of their food choices and them eating together. There is also a scene where everyone is making jewelry and playing volleyball at the beach. Some special illustrations there would have been fun too.

143164834.review:
This game is a true gem of a visual novel and I'm sad that it would've slipped under my radar if I didn't have a recommendation from someone.  

Most of this game runs like a VN but what surprises me is that no matter how many times I play it, I always find something new due to the huge amount of customization that this game offers.  The game centers around the MC, who you can customize how you like, and their new next door neighbor, Cove, and the summers they spend together.  Every chapter is broken up into what the game calls Steps, documenting little slices of life every 5 years.  The game starts you at 8, going from young teen, to older teen, and then adulthood.

There's so many different little scenes depending on your choices.  You can decide how you feel towards your neighbor, Cove, and how you approach it.  Want to go a slow burn romance route?  Or do you want to be the one to confess your feelings and take charge?  Or would you rather be confessed to?  Or would you rather declare loud and proud your feelings?  Or perhaps, you rather not bother with romance and just stay close friends?  Or maybe you want to woo another guy?  The choice is up to you!

There's so many different ways to go about your summers, and the game will know what decisions you made or what scenarios you played may come up later, or heck, if you played a scenario before another, the game will point it out!  An example of this is I remember ordering a specific drink way at the beginning of Step 2 and later on in Step 3, Cove bought me the exact same drink from back then.  Or I did one of Derek's stories and played a Cove chapter, and a character will mention the story you just played.  Your parents will bring up the troubles that you and Cove got into from Step 1.   And depending on how you play, you may meet characters much sooner than you would originally. 

Seriously, there's so many different ways to approach things that I would run out of space for it all.  I'm absolutely floored every time I play this game and make one or two different choices and the game reflects that and comes back to me somehow.  Or I still discover a piece of dialogue that I've never read.

The game can be played for free, but I'd highly recommend getting the DLC if you like the free version, it's worth it, just to see more shared moments of Cove.  Or if you decide you just want to be friends with Cove and go after the other two popular characters, Derek and Baxter.

The one thing I'd say is don't go into here expecting deep drama or angst.  While the game does cover some issues, this is more light hearted and a 'feels good' type of game.  There's also no right or wrong way to play it, it's all about what you choose and how you choose to spend your summer days.

Try out the free version, and if you like it, go after whatever DLC you want.  If you want a really feel good game or just in the mood for something light hearted, this is it.

review en español mas abajo

Wow.

Like many others have said before, It is HIGHLY recommended that you play this game like the main character is you. Technically, given the incredible amount of customization and options, there's be a lot of ways to roleplay and make whatever Jamie/PC you want, but this is a game that is both very, VERY good at hitting you on the feels and knows how to comfort you no matter what kind of person you are. Most of the choices seem like they're asking you personally anyways

I can't count the times i ended choking up, when things changed or when Cove expressed his fears, having friends drift away from your life, the ways everything changes as time goes on... 

I can't begin to describe how i felt with both the step 3 and step 4 endings. They were both so perfect and tied so well to the main theme and framing device of the story.

This was such a wild bittersweet journey of self-discovery, and I'm so glad that I got to experience it. Even though I'll never be able to replicate the feelings of my first time playing, I'll still hold the memories close to me. Maybe someday ill play completely differently to before hehe

---ESPAÑOL----

Guao

La verdad no recuerdo si el juego este disponible en Español o no. Me encantaria poder contribuir a una traducción, pero considerando todas las elecciones y como interactuan entre si, seria una tarea tremenda jajajaj.

Our Life es una novela visual MUY customizable y personal. Juegas como Jamie Last (O lo que quieras ponerle de nombre y apellido) comenzando en tu niñez (como a los 6-9 años, si mi memoria me sirve) cuando conoces por primera vez a tu nuevo vecino Cove Holden, y pasas por varias aventuras y momentos de tu vida interactuando con el.

El juego se divide en 4 pasos: Los primeros tres (niñez, adolescencia y adultez temprana) inician con un segmento de "introduccion" obligatoria, en la que sientas las bases de la clase de persona que eres. Luego vienen los "momentos", basicamente escenarios que puedes jugar en cualquier orden que gustes o incluso ignorar completamente. Mientras no estes jugando ningun momento, puedes elegir pasar a la siguiente fase, donde recibes un mini epilogo de tu ultimo dia de verano, luego del que puedes cambiar tu personaje nuevamente para el siguiente paso.

No miento cuando digo que este *tecnicamente* es un juego muy ligero, nada de violencia o muchas cosas que te harian sonrojar. Esto no significa que no tenga emocion o que te diabetes por el exceso de dulzura. La historia te hace querer a los personajes y sentir por lo que pasan. Aunque el cambio asuste y sea triste, aun hay posibilidades de tener mas momentos felices en tu vida.

Te recomendo mucho jugar si te es posible

142567172.review:
When I started playing Our Life: Beginnings & Always, I had just come off of a 250+ hour campaign of Tears of the Kingdom, and I was desperately in the mood for a narrative-heavy game with minimal action-oriented gameplay and lots of reading. Thus, I ran a search for "best visual novels," hoping to find something that would scratch the particular itch I was feeling that wasn't already in my game library. Upon finding several recommendations for Our Life, I decided it was worth a shot,. It had a cute premise with a timeskip feature I was looking for, and the overwhelmingly positive reviews on Steam--not to mention the fact that the base-game was free to play--tipped the scale even more. I went out on a limb and decided to buy all the DLC at once, wanting to experience all the game had to offer (at present) in one sitting rather than going back to cherry-pick DLC afterwards. Boy, was it worth every penny. The art style is lovely, the music is perfect (considering the small selection of songs, their importance at setting the tone, and how many hours I spent hearing them, I never got annoyed, which is a feat in itself), and the writing is exceptional.

Our Life: Beginnings & Always has the unique privilege of being in my "best games" category on Steam, a feat that only seventeen other titles have had the pleasure of achieving in ten years. I had no idea when picking up this game that I was going to be treated to some of the most beautiful, heartfelt writing I've experienced in a game. Watching the characters' lives unfold over fifteen years had me going through a rollercoaster of emotions, especially in Step 3 and 4, which had me laughing, crying (happy, sad, and angry tears), grinning like an idiot, and, quite unexpectedly, squealing and flailing. I never wanted it to end. The game tackled so many difficult subjects with such grace, maturity, and realness, and it never wavered in its overwhelmingly inclusive inclusivity. I cannot give enough praise to the writing team.

The writing for all of the characters is excellent--special shout-outs to my two loves, Noelani and Kyra, and best moody boys, Baxter and Jeremy--but there is no one quite like Cove Holden. Who knew that my unique weakness for green-haired soft bois would only become stronger through this game? I genuinely adore that man so much; I need them to keep making more DLC so I can shower him with my undying affection. Everyone needs to find their own Cove in real life. The way he and MC love each other and try to make each other happy is so beautiful. I tried to make their relationship a slow-burn, but once they hit eighteen, I couldn't pump the brakes anymore. I was in love with Cove and needed him to know it. IMMEDIATELY. I couldn't even stop myself from proposing in Step 3 after only starting dating that same summer, and when the time came to arrange the wedding, I was already chanting "POPPY HILL, POPPY HILL" before I realized that was actually going to be an option. Over and over again, things fell into place and felt so right--the pacing, the jokes, the callback moments to even the smallest of things that happened earlier in the game. Hearing characters reminisce about moments that even I had forgotten over the course of the few weeks I played it--I felt so truly immersed and connected to these characters and to the MC I was piloting and shaping over time. I have never played a true visual novel where ALL of my choices felt so fully realized in who my MC was or how her many different relationships developed over time. 

If you're thinking of playing this game or any game by GB Patch Games, I beg you to give them a try. Even if you only play the free base-game, I promise it will be more than worth your time, and you will want more. It's honestly a crime that the base-game is free because I would have paid money for it just to support the developers for creating such a beautiful story. Amazing, amazing experience.

142357109.review:
Its unbelievable, a worthwhile experience for anyone who enjoys watching the progression of your characters life. The relationships with your family, friends, and lovers are all something special to each player. There is no romance game I recommend more. While I myself became enthralled with Baxter Ward and his dramatic and heart-wrenching story, I of course like the majority of players started with Cove. I'll share my experiences with each of the three routes. 

!!!SPOILER WARNINGS AHEAD FOR EACH ROUTE!!!

Cove as the main love-interest is truly something special, and tender in his route. Your relationship with him blossoming creates a sense of fondness from Step 2. He clearly cares and adores and has some attachment issues from the divorce that plagued his early childhood. The steps truly show that you are magnets forever magnetized to eachother, holding strong as you grow. His family welcomes you and your family welcomes his. It's a perfect childhood friend romance story in a package. However, that can also be a complaint of mine. It was a bit too perfect? While there can be drama and some issues arise, it's never between you and Cove. It's always family related. I would've loved to see some turmoil that we bounce back from. But his route  is perfect for those who want a beautiful, serene, heartfelt story with progression pace chosen by the player.

Then there is Derek, who surprised me a lot. He's a family man who is a little odd in my opinion. But a sweet route if you value a very close bond with family and siblings. I don't care for his route as much as it lacked having a deeper romance between you and your mc. Or perhaps that's just how my playthrough went. There isn't much to say besides his very clear sense of responsibility for his family. Eldest child syndrome is Derek in a nutshell. It is charming however it takes up 90% of the route which frustrated me as someone who found him possibly charming in the earlier steps as children. His personality is a bit bland as well, it's unfortunate but I'm sure there will be those who disagree.

Now for who I believe to be the best written love-interest, Baxter Ward. You have the chance to meet him as a child at the soiree you attend as a dance partner. His personality is blunt, guarded, and of course someone who craves and adores the dramatic. Your story with him is one that hurts, one that could cause anger in some players and mourning in others. His story varies greatly from the others, as your first (yes, first) relationship with him is a summer fling. "A suitor for the summer". He comes across as a perfectionist who feels he must make up his self-proclaimed lack of personality with grand-scale gestures. You see parts of his craving for true closeness. Then when the summer comes to its end, he dumps you cruelly. Ghosting the player for 5 years only to be reunited by two friends' wedding. It's an emotional roller coaster and one I wish never ended. I highly suggest his route out of all three. For the rest, I leave up to you to play yourself.

142331687.review:
Satisfyingly complex and simple. Whaaaaaaaat does that mean. Basically I'm impressed with how deep the story can remember your choices of dialogue, actions, and attitudes not just for Cove but all the love interests and family/friends. The game is very wholesome and welcoming while still not being afraid to dip its toes into more challenging subjects around communication, relationships, and maturity. The kids feel believable (already an accomplishment on its own) and the adults feel casually normal.

The options for gender/body/personality customization can't be overstated. Being able to choose how you look and how you feel about *and* be able to change that later as your story grows was very interesting and not something you see as an option in a lot of games, even visual novels where your PC is invisible. 

All in all, this is always the first visual novel I rec to friends looking for one, even if they have no interest in romancing Cove, because the story can still progress as a friend or otherwise, and I'm really glad this game was able to end on such a high of all its potential routes and choices.

142275531.review:
I am so horrendously down bad for this game in a way I never would have anticipated. As a new steam user, I perused games in tags I was interested in and Our Life: Beginnings and Always was one of the ones in the otome/visual novel tag that I kept seeing. At first, I was hesitant because it was free and most popular otome titles cost actual money. But it’s free and our main boy has mint green hair (which is my weakness) so I said why not, it's free it can't hurt to try. The way this game is structured creates an atmosphere of what feels like genuine interactions with Cove and creates an immersive experience. Honestly this game is something special and I look forward to more of what GB Patch makes in the future.

Character customization for the MC is so much more in depth than most games in the genre and works seamlessly with the story. The fact that you can change what you look like and your name at designated spots in the story is innovative, appreciated, and establishes a very immersive experience. The self-inserting is done well with the choice customization and writing in general. Narration doesn't try to dictate what you do or feel unless you influence it with a choice and the characters are written to do the same thing. Never in this game have I felt like the writer wants me to feel a certain way about a plot point, you have the option to express a wide range of emotions during the story. You go at your own pace and the game respects you for it instead of punishing you. 

The story itself doesn't aim to tell anything hard hitting or deep, but instead structures itself for a feel good, tender, coming of age story. You're never set on this one path for a result that the story wants you to have; you get to choose whether you want romance or friendship or neither if you want. Freedom of choice is a primary strength to this game, and I cannot appreciate it more for it. However, any tension that crops up are usually quickly resolved or accepted with no issue. There's no allowance for an ongoing conflict besides dealing with the strain of Cove's parents' divorce and is very much dedicated to making playing the game a feel-good experience. 

I don't want to talk too much about the characters because I feel that it's best to go in blind and form your own opinions, but I'll try to be as non-revealing as possible. Cove Holden is a cutie and obviously it's already really biased of me to say so but the game does such a good job of creating fun interactions and mundane but sweet things to do I can't help but start to like him and find him relatable (as a kid of a twice divorced mom, his story arc hits a bit too close to home than what I bargained for). Everybody else you can only grow so close with. Characterization for the adults besides Kyra are almost nonexistent. They're pleasant, but they are flat. I know next to nothing about Noelani and Pamela besides how they met, Cliff runs a business but you never see it or told what it is except in DLC and he's very much just a dad character and not much beyond that, Derek's dad is mentioned in passing like once or twice but doesn't hold a presence until DLC which I find weird for someone who is a business partner of our main love interest's dad. It's clear the parents aren't supposed to play a major role in the story to allow the freedom for you and the other kids to get up to hijinks (which I am fine with) but creates this weird feeling of an ideal world with no consequences. Liz is enjoyable, Shiloh can get fucked (I just found him annoying and has nothing to do with when he grows up), Terry and Miranda needed WAY more screen time than they got to be believable friends to the MC and Cove, and Lee is cool but she could've been removed and nothing would've change which I find sad to say because she would've been a great character to create tension or drama just because of how straightforward she is. There's a wide cast of characters but their relationship to you as the MC is underdeveloped compared to Cove. I didn’t see this as an issue until I started playing Derek’s DLC which I take some issue with. I don't own Baxter's DLC and I’m not interested in playing it, but from what I've heard if you like angst and drama then go for it. Derek as a character is overall very sweet and the DLC adds a nuanced depth to him that I appreciate and wish his story was handled better.

I've already stated that I really like this game, it’s pretty much a 4.8/five for me, but no game is flawless. My number one biggest issue with this game is the CGs and how inconsistent the art seems to be. Some of them have slightly off anatomy or the perspective will look a little wonky. Some facial proportions differ slightly between CGs and the same goes for hair volume which sounds a bit nit-picky, but when it begins to look off model, I start to find that a problem. I feel like this is the most prevalent in Derek's DLC which makes me feel disappointed because home boy doesn't get a lot of CGs to begin with. I don't own Baxter's DLC so I can't say. I like Derek but there is a HEAVY focus on family as a theme in his DLC, to the point that the romance aspects are just left completely out of it. It was excusable in Step 2, but during his Step 4 epilogue I genuinely felt like I was getting rejected without it actually happening. Next to no romance occurs until basically the end and at that point it almost feels like Derek should've just got a separate game that focuses on his adult life rather than this growing up perspective. It makes me sad to say all this because I really enjoyed Derek's character and I think he's very cute, but I can't help but feel disappointed after playing his route because you'd expect more romance than what you actually get. Everything I have to say beyond this point is honestly extremely minor but still noticeable. This game has a unique operating system, so there's a lot that has to be covered to understand the mechanics of the game. And the tutorial just DUMPS it on you, and it was overwhelming enough that I almost quit.  I'm used to jumping in and figuring it out along the way, but if it's one thing I hate, it's getting a bad end because I didn’t understand the game mechanic (I'm looking at YOU DANDELION). Overall the tutorial needs to be more succinct and that’s it. The UI is very cute, love the colors, but it wasn't until I was literally almost sixty hours in that I realized that there are 40 save slot pages and not 20. The save and load buttons are also NOT next to each other and idk if that was intentional or not, but I find it would've been more convenient to have them closer because I keep clicking configure or log instead of load or save.

Despite my critiques, I still heavily enjoyed the game and all the new experiences you can get from the variety of choices and decisions you can make. It ended up hitting a lot closer to home than I ever could've anticipated it doing and can't recommend it enough. After my first play through I was genuinely shocked it was a free game. For what it gave me, it's probably worth all the DLC I bought. Also btw if you play through the game completely free and like the experience enough to play it again, it will be more efficient to buy the DLC bundle. I bought individual DLC bc I thought "oh hey I should save money and this is what I prioritize in my playing experience" only to keep playing and buy everything except for Baxter's DLC which I might just buy anyway at this rate. BTW there is a 18+ patreon DLC, the soundtrack is pleasant and feel-good, and spiritual successor coming soon!

This game is unique because it tracks multiple life stages, and it actually has a few moments that hit hard.
PROS
 - good art
 - psychology of assertiveness is really well organised (!!)
 - story arcs generally work well, especially in the lead up and execution of key moments (I cried a bit)
 - great hook at the start ;)
 - some really interesting character developments
CONS
 - shallow exploration of moral issues presented (things just are)
 - unrealistic parents all around - just not very believable
 - inconsistent story-telling quality. Sometimes the stories have me hooked, other times it's giving you too much uninteresting detail, and a few times the story is meandering with no direction (please don't "I'm bored." "What should we do next?" "I don't know." that completely stalls all narrative momentum - makes me want to skip the entire chapter. Instead try to understand WHY you need to show the reader THIS moment.)

141735236.review:
I've never done a review for a game before, so bear that in mind as you read this. I'm simply giving my thoughts and feelings, not grading it according to some set of standards or a scale.

I love this game.

I could stop there, actually, but I won't. Honestly, I started playing it and then stopped for a bit, not because of any dislike but because when I saw there were DLC's I wanted ALL OF THEM. This game charmed me from the very outset. I've not done much of the visual novel genre, in truth, and not many dating sims either, so I had little to which to compare this. Mostly I play things like Assassin's Creed, Frostpunk, Fallout, Subnautica, No Man's Sky... you get the idea. I really didn't know what to expect from this, but it was free and had an interesting concept, so I figured why not? Man, did that pay off!

If you're reading this you already know the basics of the game, so I won't rehash it. I will say that this game sucks you in. The characters are so well defined and distinctive, and even when they're being a little douche-y (the sister can be rather bossy at times) they're still loveable and you can't help feeling like you really know them. There were times when I was playing and something would happen and I couldn't help smiling and thinking "Oh, that's so Cove" or something similar. Huge props to the devs for bringing these characters to such life and making them so absorbing.

I have not finished the game. I don't play obsessively every day or anything like that, though I do go through spurts. That's just how I am in general. I'm in the adolescent stage, and I'm playing through every moment in all the DLCs because I genuinely adore this story and being able to be part of it. It always makes me smile when there's a reference to something that happened in the past that I choose; It gives the player a true sense of involvement and agency, which is wonderful.

The art is lovely, and this is coming from someone who's never really been that into the anime style of art. It works perfectly for this game, even the green hair. (As an aside, my sister does keep telling me that Cove is going to end up revealing that he's a merman. This game has NO supernatural anything in it, but she insists it will happen. She has NOT played the game, but she says that all the signs point to it. I see what she means, but I am certain she is wrong. Maybe.)

This is the game I go back to when I'm feeling moody or down, or just want something that feels good. It's playable in short spurts or longer sessions. It's incredibly inclusive without making the inclusivity feel forced. It addresses all kinds of issues that you wouldn't expect, and does so in a way that is sweet and sensitive and lovely. It's a very comforting game, and still interesting and absorbing.

I love that the game is free, but now that I've played it I would pay for it, and that's high praise from me. I want this developer to prosper because they put out a high-quality, beautiful, very carefully designed and well-executed game with lots of heart. That said, this style of game isn't for everyone, so don't go into it expecting high action or sex (Actually, I don't know about the sex since I'm still in the adolescent stage and obviously there wouldn't be any there). This is a game that focuses on a very special friendship (and romance, if you choose), and in that it excels. If that's what you're looking for, GET THIS GAME. Hell, I recommend anyone and everyone give it a shot; I mean, it's free, so why not? If you don't like it you haven't lost anything, and you might find yourself as charmed as I was. Seriously, this game genuinely took me by surprise.

Anyway, in conclusion, it's a great game that I highly recommend. Oh, and the DLCs add a lot to it as well, so I consider them quality purchases, plus it lets you support the devs who I really think deserve a lot of credit. This game was clearly a labor of love and it shows.

141705859.review:
This game is very well thought out. The characters are charming, unique and interesting, while still maintaining a sense of realism. This game is very relaxing and peaceful to play, and it's quite enjoyable replaying the game various times, testing to see what happens depending on the choices you make. 
The attention to detail, in my opinion, is insane. Every choice you make feels wrapped in a sense of importance, even if it's minuscule in the bigger picture. This might not be the case for others, but for me, that makes it feel just like real life. Seemingly small and regular moments aren't glossed over, they're put in the spotlight. That just makes this game even more beautiful. 
I also love how this game allows you to have a unique opinion on almost everything that happens, including indifference and different levels of intensity on the spectrum of good and bad. It makes every occurrence feel more natural. This game doesn't force you to like, dislike, agree with, disagree with, or do anything you don't want to. You pick how you act, and you pick which characters you want like/form a relationship with.
I'm not the kind of person to cry. I rarely ever do. But this game gave me that emotional gut feeling, as if I was on the verge of tears.
This game is truly beautiful, and super detailed. Even if you don't want to date Cove/any of the dlc guys, it's a beautiful visual novel, even without considering the romantic parts.

141582842.review:
Our Life: Beginnings & Always is an exceptional visual novel that left a profound impact on me. From its captivating storytelling to its beautifully crafted characters, every aspect of this game comes together to create an unforgettable experience.

One of the most remarkable qualities of Our Life is its ability to evoke genuine emotions. The story delves into the complexities of human relationships, exploring themes of love, friendship, and personal growth. The writing is masterfully done, effortlessly drawing you into the lives of the characters and making you genuinely care about their joys and struggles. The narrative tackles various emotional arcs with sincerity and depth, leaving you feeling both moved and introspective.

The characters in Our Life are incredibly well-developed and relatable. Each individual possesses a unique personality, and their interactions feel authentic and meaningful. I found myself genuinely connecting with them, investing in their dreams, aspirations, and personal dilemmas. The character development throughout the game is expertly executed, allowing you to witness their growth and transformation over time.

The art style of Our Life is visually stunning, with its charming, hand-drawn illustrations and beautifully designed backgrounds. The attention to detail is evident in every scene, enhancing the immersion and bringing the world to life. The soundtrack is equally enchanting, perfectly complementing the mood and ambiance of each moment.

One of the standout features of Our Life is the freedom of choice it offers. The decisions you make throughout the game have tangible consequences, shaping the direction of the story and the relationships you form. This level of interactivity adds an exciting layer of engagement, making each playthrough a unique and personal experience.

Moreover, the inclusivity and diversity portrayed in Our Life are commendable. The game embraces characters from different backgrounds, representing various ethnicities, genders, and sexual orientations. It promotes understanding, empathy, and acceptance, fostering an inclusive atmosphere that is both refreshing and empowering.

Finally, I must commend the developers for their ongoing commitment to improving the game. They actively listen to feedback from the community, regularly releasing updates and patches to enhance the gameplay experience and address any concerns.

In conclusion, Our Life: Beginnings & Always is a truly remarkable visual novel that shines in every aspect. Its powerful storytelling, well-crafted characters, stunning visuals, and meaningful choices make it an absolute joy to play. I wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone seeking an immersive and emotionally resonant experience. Prepare to embark on a heartfelt journey that will leave a lasting impression on your heart and mind.
