141047704.review:
Our Life: Beginnings & Always is a story that changes depending on the choices you make throughout it. You choose who you want to be and the relationships you'd like to have.

Personally, I stayed as true to the person I was at the different ages which I think added an extra layer of fun and interesting. I also decided early on that if I was playing through it anyway, I may as well get all the DLCs to get the full experience.

[b] Art [/b]
I absolutely love everything about this art style. It's a beautiful blend of different colours that didn't feel too harsh. The backgrounds are fantastic, I don't think I have a single bad thing to say about them. The multiple expressions on the characters was a nice touch that not many people who make Visual Novels do. They tend to stick with a neutral expression which is fine but I'm glad that the people here went the extra mile. I also adored the attention to detail, even the smallest ones.

[b] Characters [/b]
The characters feel more real than some people IRL do. That takes skill to make them that believable. There's an assortment of characters you can get to know: Your moms, your sister, your sister's friend, your neighbour, your neighbour's father, etc. There are much more after these.

Here are my thoughts on some of them:

Your moms are solid all-around – not too harsh but also not lenient. I found them to be an excellent blend of bad humour that only parents are capable of and incredibly loving but not to the point where it's annoying.

Your sister is a brat at first but eventually comes around. I'll be honest, I didn't like her at all in step one. She was so bossy to the point where I wanted her to shut up. But somewhere in step two, I went from that to not minding her presence and eventually came to like her sassiness. The fact that she likes to tease too is also kind of fun.

Your neighbour is by far my favourite character in this whole game. There were so many similarities between the two of us. Possibly because [spoiler] we're both autistic, [/spoiler] something that's not revealed until much later. I called that very early on. At the time, I didn't know if I was just projecting or if that's where we were heading. But I'm glad that I was right and it's so nice to see a character like that.

[b] Music [/b]
The music's lovely. It's not anything grand that I'll add into my collection of game soundtracks. That doesn't mean it's bad, it just didn't blow me away.

[b] Story [/b]
The story's fairly straightforward and if you have all the DLCs there's so much more to explore. The content in this game is insane. The fact that you can basically build your own character from the ground up is nuts. And I love that! I enjoyed playing as close to myself as I possibly could. I say that because there's no dropout option, you have to be successful in some way in this. Which is a little meh but I guess it makes sense.

The story I chose was that my neighbour and myself ended up as a couple. I have yet to explore the wedding DLC but I doubt that I'll not have fun with it.

[b] Text [/b]
Overall, I would give the text a 6.5/10. You may ask, “Why so low?” Because I can't tell you how many times it immediately took me out of the story as I noticed something or another, repeatedly.

First things first, there are way too many “started” and “began” words. These are good placeholders but should be removed before publishing. The reason I bring this up is because after a while, I couldn't enjoy myself fully as I kept getting distracted.

You also need more variation. There's one moment in step three where the word “contentedly” or “content” kept being used. I also found “bent smile” seven times in step four, never mind in the other moments. There's no shame for a writer to look up synonyms – most of us do it.

I'd say that the writing got worse after step one. Other than all of that, it's pretty good. I mean, I managed to enjoy myself in the end. But I'm still disappointed.

TL;DR
Our Life: Beginnings & Always is more than just a game, it's an experience.

140981863.review:
So, here´s the thing, and I thought long and hard how to leave this review:

The main characters to “choose” from are a masterpiece; Cove, Derek and Baxter are extremely lovable. Their personality built is deeper and more consistent than any other game I´ve seen. Their narrative is exquisite and the fact that the game lets you find aspect of the characters that you´ll find in a real person after you know them better, it´s beyond appealing.
My real problem with the game is: There are no true consequences to anything.

You can make choices and the text will slightly change but the endings are straight out the same. If you reject any of them nothing happens, you are taking back on track to the original text with the same phrases they just change "boyfriend" for "friend", or they skip the other phrases where they say words of love or liking.
I think this game has MANY unnecessary options, the fact that it´s more important for them to make me decide if I´m ok with my body or if I have body dysphoria is concerning. This is a dating sim, why is so focused if I have mental issues or not?
I want to go to places with the characters, pick if I can be intimate with them or not, if want to change the story and do something different... not if I´m going to choose a vegan bread or not... it´s ridiculous how many time the game spent trying to make you feel "accepted" and "special" instead of guiding a story with the three main boys. 

Don´t get me wrong, I LOVE THIS GAME WITH PASSION, my 300+ hours prove it. I just think it could have been less intrusive in regards of "me", and I would like to have more options for different endings or more everything for the three main options of loving boys, than if I pick a chair to sit or the couch :/

Anyway, I love Baxter with all my being, That´s it

140913899.review:
THANK YOU GB PATCH FOR LETTING ME GROW UP WITH COVE HOLDEN! <3

Let me start off with the technical aspect of the game. Visual-wise, it's great! I have minor problems with the CGs but it didn't really affect my gaming experience much since it portrays the scene well. The way it was drawn, especially some of the DLCs on steps 3-4, it doesn't sit well with me personally. The mechanics of the game are quite amazing. I used to play the game from left to right, but then once I experimented on things, some events affect another event if played in an order. Sometimes, certain dialogue choices can have an impact on how the world of Sunset Bird responds to you. I even saw screenshots or comments that I personally haven't experienced in game. This game can be played a thousand times and there are some small dialogues that you might have missed. It would be nice however if we somehow knew Xavier during the wedding since I have the Derek DLC and had met them at the boardwalk. Music is great, a bit redundant but portrays the scene really well. Voice-acting is limited but you can always feel the emotion when it's there. Story-wise, well, this is the best story and world-building I've ever read. Players also have the ability to change the affection level of the MC to the love interest. However, you can only change it upwards, and you can't pursue other love interests without the DLC. And you might find yourself asking, is it work it to buy the DLCs and I would say yes. The story is already amazing without the DLCs but having them adds a whole new flavor. It enhances the game to perfection.

Now for the characters themselves.

I have played several visual novels in my life but nothing can come close to this masterpiece. I was just scrolling through STEAM and Itch.io to play any visual novels during the pandemic. It was one of my ways to pass the time. Then the beginning of December, I found this game. I was immediately hooked by the premise and the price tag that of free to play. I remember feeling nothing about this since most free to play visual novels are good but not really tear-inducing. I didn't even like Cove's design? Like Jeremy said, he has stupid eyebrows. And I disliked the color green. But now, all I can think about is his wavy green hair, and his tear-stained face.

Cove Holden is the main love interest in this story. Of course, you have the option to just be friends with him or continue just being an acquaintance. You are free to choose what relationship you want to have with him. But for me, the best thing to experience OLBA (Our Life: Beginning and Always) is having him as a partner. I don't really have the words to describe Cove. He's an ocean-loving dork who likes mermaids. He's a sensitive and emotional person and values every little thing and moment that you have with him. He's shy, easily gets flustered, and is very clingy and spoiled. Cove Holden is the best person to ever existed in fiction, and in reality, like my fellow players wished for. Catching the fireflies with him, our adventures on the beach, and most of all, a Cove Holden trait, him climbing up your bedroom window. It was honestly funny for me. He's there when you are in your darkest moments just like when he's at his. My world honestly became brighter because of Cove. And a little bonus, he's the only person that calls you, with his voice, that you can hear. I kept loading the times he called me by name. It's better to play the game to fully experience that is the sweet cinnamon roll.

Derek Suarez, a DLC love interest. Like Cove, you have the option to be lovers, friends, or not. I have played his Step 4 a year ago and I haven't played it again so my opinion of him as a grown adult is well, limited. From what I can recount, he is a sweet guy. But he is TOO responsible for his own good. As the eldest, he had overseen his brothers for the longest time and had to be the mature one. I like his design but I guess he really didn't click with me much. I recommend to see other reviews if you are interested with him.

Baxter Ward, another DLC love interest that was just released recently as of writing this. Like the two love interests, you can pursue him to be your lover, friend, or just an acquaintance. I just played the DLC recently and had been intrigued by him even from before. At first, his forwardness weirded me out. Especially when he is makind advances (?) towards Cove and the MC. But as I got to know his story, I sympathized with him. I also have this mindset that I cannot be 'the one' in someone else's life. Like the MC stated, leaving behind footprints in the sand if I remembered correctly. I have friends but I don't really feel close to them and keep on having barriers around me, putting people at arm's length. I honestly disliked Baxter as I first played this game but as time goes on, I grew to appreciate this monochromatic guy. He can be forward and smooth, but so awkward with letting his feelings known. Cove Holden can be awkward but his feelings are honest. He cries when he's sad, happy, and frustrated, but Baxter Ward just runs away, like me. I guess I have a lot to say about this guy since he reminds me of myself too much.

For the other characters, they're honestly great. Noelani and Pamela are great moms, sweet but strict. They are very understanding and are quite nice people. Liz or Elizabeth reminds me a lot of my sassy sister. Lee resembles my cute cousin whom I'm very close with. Miranda and Terry are just so cute! I wish I could be as open with my friends in real life like here in fictional SoCal.

Now, for Shiloh and Jeremy. They are characters and love interests from XOXO Droplets. I played that game before OLBA and since I'm broke, my main love interest was Shiloh. He's at his worst in OLBA or I just didn't notice how much of a handful he is in XOXO Droplets since the MC there has an equally horrible attitude. Or there are less interactions there because of the game system. I don't know but I swear, Shiloh really gets on my nerves more than Jeremy.

Anyways, please do give this game a try! It's really fun and I swear, you would not leave Sunset Bird anytime soon. It's been 2-3 years since I've played this game and I always found myself here in this small tourist trap town. Sunset Bird is one of my homes and I hope it can be yours too. To Cove Holden, you never left my mind ever since I saw you on that white poppy hill. I love you in the beginning and always <3

140866501.review:
I could ramble on about this game forever, honestly. You may be able to tell from my play time that this has become one of my top go-to comfort games. If you're  into visual novels/RPGs at all I'd say this game is WELL worth a try. The DLCs add even more detail and characters and are, in my opinion, far more than worth the price.

This game is beautiful both visually and thematically, the characters are detailed and lovable, PLUS one of the main characters is canonically on the autism spectrum. You can play your relationship with Cove as a friendship or something more (there's a sort of spectrum of options), and no matter what you choose you get a detailed and fun storyline you can replay over and over again. The DLCs add two more character storylines (which can also be played as friends or more) that add even more rich storytelling to the game. Plus, there's an abundance of options, both in-game and settings wise, for customizing your character's gender expression, pronoun preferences, and other details, although the physical appearance of your character is only seen in the 'in-between' steps between each section of the game and not in the game itself outside of a few bonus images.

Overall, if you enjoy exploring how your actions effect the game world, if you enjoy very cute and emotionally rich storylines, and if you spend hours reading fanfiction of the same two characters meeting and falling in love over and over, you're going to love this game.

140863886.review:
What a lovely game. 

This is the first visual novel I've ever played, and I feel like it's set the bar quite high for anything else to compare to. Getting to experience unconditional love and acceptance, no matter who you choose to be in the game, felt like a breath of fresh air. I could be myself, at least as close to as the game allows, and nobody ever batted an eye. I could be who I am and that was that. No questions asked, no doubts from anybody, they just love and accept you for who you are. 

By the time I got to the moments in Step 1, I knew this was going to be a really, [b]really[/b] good experience. I bought all the DLCs and played through every moment. I couldn't get away from this game; it's just so incredibly lovely. Getting to experience such an amazing childhood with the family, friends and Cove was such a joy. It's like I got to experience something I never had myself, growing up. I know it's a bit dramatic, but I really enjoyed the moments and the writing during the first two steps. This may be fictional, but it's something I'm going to cherish for a long time.

This also applies to the other steps; the writing is excellent throughout, though I did disagree with where 2 of the moments went; they go in a direction that I never would, nor had I ever gone in my playthrough until then because it was forced on me. It's nothing terrible, but to be specific without spoiling anything, I would never start a fight with someone and the game pretty much forced it. Didn't think that was really fun, not gonna lie; but that's my one and only complaint about the game.

Also, the game doesn't force you to get involved romantically with anyone. If that's not your thing, you can play through it without that, and that's perfectly fine! You're free to make those decisions; you don't get forced into anything like that.

I don't think I can really do this game justice with anything else I could write here. If you like VNs and want something chill and wholesome, then why not give this a try? After all, it's free.

140826338.review: I didn't have high hopes for this game but I can't even begin to try to put it into words just how wonderful this game is; the art, the story, the characters, it had made me so emotional I didn't expect for this game to be this amazing let alone have this kind of impact on me. This game really made me look back on my own life, I seriously wish I could of experienced even just alittle bit of what this game shows, even so this game does help give you a bit of that experience; the only disappointing thing about playing this game is knowing I won't find something similar, not even something remotely close. I can only hope the dev can makes something just as amazing as this again.

140826261.review:
Lets run down the list of all the things that are great about this game:

Free base game with cheap expansion
Lovely Art
Nice Characters that actually grow as people
Tackles a relatable issue of how much life can change, yet somethings always stay the same
Innocent, shy boi love interest
The fact that you are not forced you be in a relationship with said love interest
You are able to change a lot about your character, and it still feels like your character is there in the world, even if you never see them
The feeling that the world and the people you spend time with actually grow with you, and it isn't bullshitting about it either. It genuinely feels like a different playthrough depending on your thoughts about Cove at the beginning, so there is some replay-ability despite only having the one romantic interest
Truly happy, sad, funny, and bittersweet moments
LGBTQ+ that doesn't feel forced

And the best part:
No adult content forced into the game that would have killed whatever good vibes it was going for, while still making your relationship feel as passionate or intimate as you want

The con:
It's a visual novel. If they aren't your bag, you are going to, unfortunately, miss out on a really good story

100/10

I absolutely cannot believe they were just GIVING this game away for FREE. The base game itself took me around 4 1/2 hours to finish and it was such a nice experience. After said 4 1/2 hours of gameplay, I got the ending where I was dating Cove but hadn't advanced the relationship(my sad, cold little heart fears commitment), and there was still so much to do. I still had options for my relationship status with Cove, my dialogue options, my character settings, etc. There is so much to do in this game and I can tell that it was made with complete love and care. I'm looking forward to playing the DLC(i know i said i fear commitment but i wanna marry baxter)!

The story is emotional and it portrays life. Nothing extreme, nothing crazy out of the ordinary, it's just exactly as it says. Life. And let me tell you, that is a BIG breath of fresh air after playing so many fantasy/action games. I need a break from fantasy RPGs and platformers, so a point and click was a nice change of pace for me. 
The game has pleasant music as well. Nothing memorable, but it makes nice background noise while you play. In the base game, you only have the option to date Cove, who's basically the secondary protagonist. There is DLC available for about 5 bucks each that gives you access to other characters(baxter my beloved), and all the characters are pretty likable. The game can be a bit slow at times, but it's a portrayal of life, what can you expect?
So, I know some people may be a bit wary about dating sims for....reasons, so I just want to give a bit of an overview for people who are maybe a bit unsure about the game. This game has no nudity. There are a few pretty characters put in but they're all fully clothed so it's not even a slight problem. When you get to about step three you get to choose Cove's interest/intimacy(?) can't remember the word, but basically you get to choose how, well, intimate you want to be with Cove. Setting it on a low level will tame things, which is what I did, seeing as I like romance, but with a few lines drawn. High level makes Cove able to be more intimate with you, so if you're not into that then set it on low. The game is very tame for a dating sim, but  it IS a dating simulator and it contains, well, romance, and I can understand why some people aren't into it. The game has no nudity, but there are suggestive themes and such, so I'd recommend it for about 12 and up.

Honestly one of my favourite games, it's unreal how much I love this game. It is everything I love about visual novels rolled into one:
The "cheating" ability to scroll back and pick a different option
Character customisation of not only your own character but others (rare on both counts)
Strong yet complex and interesting characters to meet and get to know
Strong / varied choices that make it easy to build a real personality for your character rather than being a blank slate
Past choices, even small ones, being brought up through out the rest of the game and actually affecting the game play instead of being forgotten.

This is an amazing game and I cant wait to see the up and coming "Our life: now and forever" and any future productions in this series!

140144932.review:
Oh my stars above this game is amazing. This game (and the PLI within) captured me instantly. Well written story, artfully composed characters. I am not sure how I feel when I admit I genuinely fell in love with Cove (no judging me, I have nothing/no-one else, stfu) so job very well done. A couple of quibbles I have include the fact that some backgrounds were a little overused (I'm thinking of the parking lot in particular) the more interactive portions felt a bit clunky (the rock paper scissors having no rng whatsoever for example) and too few, and the 3rd stage felt a little short (though that could well be me). If you want to play this game with the best experience possible without wasting money, I suggest buying the DLC like so:
Buy Step expansions 1 and 2 before starting.
Play until you meet derek (step 2), then when you get to the moments menu, then decide whether you want the Derek's story DLC.
At step 3 you should have an idea of whether you're interested in going further with Cove, so you can make an educated decision on whether getting the step 3 expansion and the wedding story are a good idea.
In addition, you meet Baxter in step 3, so once you've met him you can decide whether you want anything more to do with him.
I write this little buyer's guide because I ended up buying the lot without even looking at the trailers. All I saw was Cove and that's all I needed to see. It turned out I didn't like Derek (he makes me uncomfortable) so getting his DLC was not much use. I don't regret the purchase at all though; the happiness, bliss, and feelings of interpersonal connection this game afforded me that I never get IRL made it worth every penny of the $40NZD I spent on it. Thank you, devs, for creating it. ^-^

140141921.review:
Our Life: Beginnings & Always is a gem in the visual novel genre that stands out for its attention to detail in player choices and character development. While it could be classified as an otome game due to its exclusively male love interests, the game extends its inclusivity by allowing players to choose their own gender.

As someone who rarely dabbles in otome games, the absence of female love interests is a noticeable limitation. The potential to explore romantic narratives with characters like [strike] Lee or even Elizabeth[/strike] would have added an extra layer of depth and choice to the game. However, I can imagine the difficulty of these so let's forget about that. Our Life: Beginnings & Always manages to reel players in with its engrossing narrative and impactful choices.

The game's standout feature is undoubtedly its respect for player decisions. Every choice made significantly alters the narrative and is reflected in the dialogues, creating a truly personalized gaming experience. It's a testament to the developers' commitment to delivering a game where your choices genuinely matter.

Although a free-to-play game, several key moments are tucked behind paid DLC. However, the investment is worth it. The caliber of the writing, the immersive genre, and the beautiful accompanying music all work in harmony to create an engaging narrative experience. The cost of the DLC feels justified given the quality of the content it unlocks.

The main male love interest's narrative arc is compelling, tracing his journey from a meek boy to a mature character tailored to appeal to the player's tastes. But it's not just the end result that is intriguing; the process of growth and evolution itself is beautifully depicted and contributes to the overall appeal of the game.

One of the most engaging aspects of Our Life: Beginnings & Always is the sheer variety of outcomes possible through different player choices. The narrative is flexible enough to warrant multiple playthroughs, each offering a new perspective on what could happen if a different path is chosen.

In conclusion, Our Life: Beginnings & Always is an engaging visual novel that excels in its emphasis on player choices and character development. Despite leaning towards the otome genre, it doesn't limit itself and offers a wide range of experiences. The game's respect for player choices, combined with the quality of its narrative and DLC content, makes it an intriguing choice for fans of visual novels.

its only been half an hour and ive cried twice. growing up in a cis-het family as the only queer person there has been hard. i didnt have any other lgbtq+ friends at all growing up, nor parents that took my problems seriously. one scenario in game is having your 2 moms concernedly looking for you as a kid gives me all the things i wanted. a queer family where i didnt feel alone, and parents who actually cared.

another edit: this game helped me go from trans girl to non-binary, and i have never felt so free and happy in my life.

edit: after spending so much more time with Cove, and seeing him grow up, i started over, looking back again, and i have rediscovered who i was, repressed as a child. seeing things through this perspective again jolted my emotions from that small suppressed child i was so long ago, into the mind of the adult i am now. its too bad i never got to meet who i was, that kid. the kid who never thought he would survive. but now i see him in the photograph in my mind, like an old family friend. i love him, and i miss him. i would love to get to know him, but that time is passed. now all i can do is live on in that child's memory. and i plan to, wearing his emotions on my sleeve like a badge of honor. im gonna protect whats left of this kid. and make sure that, in some small way, he gets to see and experience the life he never had.

Welcome home, Joshua. My name is Elise, and I am going to be taking care of you from now on. Your life gets better, starting now.

139708053.review:
This game showed up randomly while i was browsing through steam and at first i wasn't expecting it to be much more than just a short and average visual novel but i noticed it featured customisation which seemed like a nice gimmick, what i wasn't expecting was to be a well thought out touching VN that had me hooked the moment i booted it up, while this game doesn't have a wide variety of songs like life is strange the music it did have really helped set the mood the game was going for with it's quiet normal life feel.

Our Life B&A goes truly in depth with how you want the MC to look and act, what their hobbies are and how you treat the people around you, even some of the small choices you made will have lasting effects with your friends or family remembering the things you do or say to them which really helps bring a lot of life into it. 

The game has 4 stages to your life, childhood, teen, young adult and adult with each stage letting you customise yourself and offers you a decent amount of things to do in each stage with cove and the other friends you can make, each moment you play through feels perfectly made, it gives you enough dialogue and choices with the people you interact with to make it feel more like you're actually a person there instead of just reading dialogue and being the third wheel to the group of friends before you and each moment never feels like it's stretching too long.

It took be about 30 hours to finish the first playthrough (with most of the DLCs) and it left me with a bittersweet feeling, while i'll never be able to play this gem of a VN for the first time again the time i spent on this was well worth it, every stage of life was perfectly sculpted with enough dialogue for everyone, no character felt like they took up room just to have them be the focus and each person has their own personality that meshed or clashed with other people in a way that felt believable between them while also including you, if you're a fan of games with a good story and like making choices that matter you owe it to yourself to playthrough this masterpiece that i feel has that golden standard for VNs that put it up there with other gems like katawa shoujo.

The time i spent in this quiet town of sunset bird was truly a unforgettable adventure and i hope everyone unsure about this game takes the plunge to try it themselves, you won't regret it.

139600321.review:
Haven't finished the game yet but I'm a fair ways in and I really like it a lot! The writing is good imo, the story is super sweet. So far, I would say it's mostly slice-of-life with some (optional!) romance.

The best part of the game imo is how your character is treated in the story. It's hard to describe, but if you choose to make the main character similar to yourself, and make choices that you might make in real life, the story starts to feel quite personal to you. I definitely recommend playing the game like that.

My [b]favorite[/b] thing that I am quite impressed with is how the game handles LGBTQ+ content regarding your character. You can choose to change your character's pronouns and name later on in their life. The other characters in the story acknowledge these changes, so it doesn't feel like an empty choice. And there are moments where your character reflects on how they feel about themself. One particularly striking moment for me was being able to choose how my character felt about their body and gender, and then telling Cove that I was thinking about getting gender-affirming surgery, and he responded so sweetly. There are several moments like that throughout the game. The love interests will ask you what genders you're attracted to, if any. I think it's all handled so well.

I wasn't sure if I'd like slice-of-life, but: The way the game is set up, each "moment" is like 10-30 minutes of reading, short but satisfying summer moments that happen throughout your character's life. So even if you're getting tired of one moment, you know you'll be done with it soon and can move onto the next one. And, the setting (a beautiful beachy town near a touristy city) is so pretty, and the artwork and music make it almost dreamy. In a setting like this, it's hard for me to get bored by the slice-of-life.

If you like romancing guys at all in your games, you will probably find something to like in one of the three(?) love interests (provided you buy the Derek and Baxter DLCs). Each love interest feels complex, and they're all quite sweet in their own way. You might get a little bored if you don't like slice-of-life and opt out of all the romance, though. In that case I would recommend trying the base game for free before purchasing any DLC to see how you feel about the slice-of-life first.

Speaking of the DLCs, personally I think they're all worth it so far, but even if you don't buy them, I think you could still enjoy the main story. The DLCs appear to add extra "moments". Without them, you still have I think 5 moments for each part of the character's life. The Derek and Baxter DLCs add additional moments centered around them as well. However, even if you choose not to romance them, you can still experience sweet moments with them as their friend.

I'll update this if I think of anything else I want to mention after I finish the game!

Played through the game in one day. It was a fun, immersive, and emotionally gripping experience, and I barely scratched the surface on content. How is this free. 

If I had any complaint at all, it might only be that the epilogue is very, very, very long. But it might only have felt that way because it was nearly midnight last night and I very badly wanted to go to sleep, but couldn't because I was in the epilogue and obviously I couldn't stop the game in the EPILOGUE. It was almost over! Five more minutes, I'm sure! (It was not five more minutes.) 

...Anyway, this might not actually be a flaw. Could be a feature. Probably depends on your vicinity to bedtime. 

*Warning to Steam Deck users, you WILL have to use desktop mode to get through the first character creation of a new game. There is no way around this. Unlike other games of the same stripe, it does not patiently wait for you to summon the keyboard screen on your own. It will very helpfully force it up for you as soon as the screen loads and you will NOT be able to get it to go away again. Even if you try to use the Steam overlay menu, you are still on the keyboard. Even when you are desperately trying to turn the Deck off, you are still on the keyboard. In your dreams that night, you will still be on the keyboard. I had to forcibly power down my Deck to get out, and then promptly did it again two more times just to be SURE. Proton might have a fix, but I haven't found it yet. To be safe, I suggest using Desktop mode, then swapping back to the handheld mode for actual gameplay. It's a little bit of a hassle, but the game is worth it.

All I can really think to say is a genuine, heartfelt thank you to everyone who made this game. I don't remember the last time that a game has hit me so hard with every end of the emotional spectrum before. I went from smiling and laughing at the inside jokes that each of the characters had made up, to tearing up whenever they shared their worries and fears, to crying so hard I had to step away for a moment during the Wedding finale.

I normally don't vibe well with most VN's for one reason or another, but with the combination of how deeply you can customise the player character, how organically the characters act and react to things that happened in earlier scenes, and just how damn well written everyone was grabbed my heart and didn't let go even after the credits rolled. And the music, too, it's simple but every track fits in exactly where it plays perfectly, whether it's one of the tracks you hear in almost every scene or if it's one that only plays once or twice in the entire game.

I hope this game, and all the characters in it, live on in my heart and mind for years to come. This game utterly deserves that Overwhelmingly Positive rating.

139108389.review:
I've had this game for years now, but never reviewed it. With the release of the Baxter DLC I figured I'd fix that.
Potential spoilers ahead.

I loved Our Life: Beginnings & Always before we got any DLC. Cove was so sweet, and it was nice to have a character be understanding when I played a mostly silent MC. Plus I love how customisable the MC is, from what they wear to physical traits. My only critique would be I wish there were more silent/quiet options that weren't disinterested or outright uncaring. There were a few times I picked a quiet option and MC started talking like they didn't care or were annoyed, and I didn't have a sympathetic option so MC had to speak when I didn't want to. It didn't ruin the experience but was a bit disappointing.
Cove himself is darling. I like that, rather than outright turning him into an extrovert, you can help him socialise on his terms. And even if he stays quiet and withdrawn it isn't treated as him 'not getting better' or something he has yet to overcome. Cove really felt like that friend who could tell the difference from an actual angry face and a resting b*tch face.
As for the 'spicy' scene, I think it was handled well with Cove. While I wouldn't say no to 'fade-to-blacks' or 18+ DLC, I'm content with what we got and think it fits GB Patch's style. Baxter was a bit different, but I'll get there.

Derek is an alright character. Before the DLC I just couldn't connect with him, and to be fair I'm still finishing his DLC. That being said: my opinion hasn't changed much. I like him more, but this DLC has me more intrigued by Jorge than Derek himself. I'm currently in the Derek Epilogue, but I'm struggling because I'm still not invested in Derek himself. So far, while I don't regret getting the Derek DLC, I'm liking it more for Derek's family and expanding MC's relationships/personality than Derek himself. While it made sense story-wise, I think the absence of Derek in Step 3 didn't help endear him to players like me.
Maybe if he had more phone calls throughout Step 3 so it actually felt like we stayed in touch?

Edit: Having finished Derek's epilogue I can sadly confirm that Derek didn't click with me either romantically (compared to Cove and Baxter) or platonically (compared to Jorge). He's by no means a bad character, I don't dislike him or think he takes away from the story, he's just kinda there. One thing I do like is that he can develop romantic feelings regardless of whether you pursue him or not. It helps give the feeling of things developing outside MCs decisions and choices.

And then there's Baxter. I always thought he was an interesting character, but after playing his DLC I don't know if I can go back to Cove X'D
I love dramatic romances, it's a weakness of mine. But I love how GB Patch approached a character with Baxter's issues. He almost feels like a 'What If' version of Cove: What if you met Cove later? What if Cove didn't open up to you? What if Cove really was alone?
Baxter shows himself as easy-going and eccentric-in-a-fun-way. But in reality he is lonely and constantly critiquing himself, spiralling over the smallest misstep he makes. He not only can't accept MC's feelings(romantic or platonic), he outright rejects the notion of his own worth.
With a shared history, it's easy to get someone to open up about issues and feelings. Not only does Baxter focus on your lack of history, he firmly rejects any attempts to reach out to him. And unlike so many other games, you can't reach him. Love doesn't magically make him open up. He leaves.
It isn't until late in his epilogue that you can potentially get back together. And even after that, Baxter still struggles. He still reflexively tries to exclude himself, distance himself, and blame himself. In fact, while you can confess around the half-way point if you wait for him to confess he waits until nearly the end.
If Cove is a puppy you found at the beach, then Baxter is a kitten you rescued from a thorn bush. Some thorns got in there good, but with love, patience, and care he can heal and finally have the people he deserves in his life.
Now, the 'spicy' scene. Like Cove's, I thought it was good and fit the style, but I do have one thing to say: I think the option to take his shirt off felt forced. Not that MC forced Baxter to do it, but like GB Patch felt they had to go farther with Baxter than they did with Cove. That in and of itself isn't bad, I approve of stretching your boundaries if you want, but since it's just a make-out session it felt like an odd interaction. It read to me like Baxter was about to lead to a 'fade-to-black'(as I think would still fit GB Patch) but suddenly remembered he wasn't in an 18+ game. Not disappointed, but definitely felt out of place. And I know you have the option not to do that with Baxter, but since I read it I'd figure I'd give my take.

Final thoughts: Baxter Marriage DLC when? XD

138951633.review:
I admit, my first impressions of the game was the same as meeting Baxter: "Oh dear." (No offense to Baxter fans) I was a bit worried as the game had advertised Cove as the player's main love interest, so it was pretty much make or break it. And the game succeeded pretty well. 

Pros:
1) Cove's relatability is written extremely well in my personal opinion. As someone who hates sudden changes, I related a lot with Cove's fear of things changing.
2) I liked that the game is diverse in the LGBT and race sides, without shoving it in my face and making a big "Hoo-Hah" about it. It's just a game that just so happens to have people who are of those communities. 
3) Repeatability. I like that there are so many hidden scenarios in the game that you can unlock by replaying it like if you choose to keep Cove's dolphin key-chain charm, Cove will comment on it or if you wear an anklet he also comments on it. 
4) The nostalgic feel of the game. I don't know how to describe it, but the game just creates a nostalgic feeling through the music, the scenarios, the characters, and the writing. 
5) The writing is entertaining, even though the scenarios are mostly real-life related, it draws you to imagine yourself actually being there with Cove or the other characters. It feels like stories that can occur in real life with your actual friends and families. I never thought I would experience something similar to Persona 4 in this game. 

Cons: 
1) Didn't really understand what's the point of a customizable character, when we don't even see them. At best we just see the main character's lips or hand.  I wish that maybe the game could have placed the main character at the corner of the game to show their reactions and emotions considering we can choose how to feel towards Cove, but since this is for the self-insert kind of players I can see why the creator chose not to do so. 
2) Oh boy, incoming hot-take here: In my honest opinion, as much as I adore and love Cove, he is way too passive. sure he gets irritated when you tease him or disagree with him but he mostly whines for a bit and that's kinda it. even most of the initiative in my opinion is done by me, which is nice to an extent but...y'know the meme of the figure poking something with a stick to see if the thing does something? yea, kinda felt that was me. I wish Cove was a bit more initiative and I played the game on direct love, to see how direct he could get, and even then... I still felt he wasn't initiating enough. 
3) Too many pointless choices: choosing an imaginary sandwich for my mc, what my mc wants to eat, what kind of food the mc eats... I felt like the game could have used those choices for more nostalgic scenarios with Cove, Baxter or Derek in my honest opinion. Also, felt it was a chore to keep clicking the screen for choices that most likely wouldn't affect how the game would be. 
4) Found it slightly creepy that we the player can just change Cove's looks, clothes, and even his personality in the first game. I understand that the point of the game is to create your perfect Cove Holden, but I felt kinda creepy that I can just do so on my first playthrough. 
5) The explanations for which choices affected Cove's personality were too vague in my opinion, so I didn't like how I had to experiment for a bit to get the perfect Cove. I know we can adjust his personality, but since the point of the game is to choose your choices to create your perfect Cove, it kinda ruins the challenge the game posed on the player as it feels like you're cheating. Maybe they add a chart of which decisions affects Cove's personality like whether he is warm, cold, sporty or studious...etc. 

Overall, a really chill game with a nostalgic and homely vibe. the end of the game is also extremely heart-wrenchingly sad, but in a good way. Its like saying farewell to a good friend that you'll most likely never see again. It sure as hell made me cry tears of sadness.

138805636.review:
I barely have words to describe the impact this game had on me, but I guess that now the story has finally come to a close, I better put my 200 hours to use.

Our Life is beyond anything I’ve ever played. I’ve never seen such a perfect depiction on what it feels to be a perfectly imperfect human being, of how it feels to grow up, to truly love and be loved, and to understand, accept and cherish the people and the moments around you, big or small. Our Life brought me newfound appreciation for life, and a new understanding of what it means to care for the people I love and want around. This game is a lesson on how to be kinder, to yourself and others, and a reassurance that you’re never truly alone.

Now for the practicalities, this vn has an incredible amount of personalization, from your appearance to your tastes and hobbies, to your emotions and involvement with the characters, and it all matters in some way (to the extent of shaping your neighbor’s personality, but scientists are still trying to figure out how that works lol). You could spend the whole game ignoring your illustrious neighbor or you could be the love of his life. Everything you pick matters, but there are no mistakes to be made, and all the wrongs can become rights. As someone who can be controlling at times, this game serves me as a reminder that people are lenient and everything is gonna be okay in the end. It always is.

It’s also absurd to me how it manages to be free and the DLC to be so affordable. The 200 hours didn’t come from nowhere, and I think all the money I spent on this franchise becomes pennies by the hour counting all the time I put into it. On the other hand, it being free was what drew me to try the game in the first place, and I couldn’t have been more pleasantly surprised.

In summary, Our Life upped my standards for visual novels astronomically, and although I don’t think I’ll ever be as moved by a game as this one has moved me, I can’t wait to see what GB Patch has in store for the future. I hope you find the same level of comfort while playing this game as I have, and that you have the sweetest life <3

138669230.review:
So, I've been playing Our Life since shortly after it was released, but I wanted to wait until all the DLC was out before I gave it a review. Honestly, this is probably one of most feel-good visual novels I've ever played in my life. It's not going to be for everyone - if you like your stories dramatic, or you like to lose yourself in something that's already fully planned out, then this might not be your style. Our Life is one of those games where you have a thousand choices - some large, like whether or not you care for someone or can forgive them, and some small, like whether or not you feel comfortable hugging your best friend's mom - and some of them change the story completely, while others just serve to make the story feel like [i]your[/i] story.

I've played this game countless times, and every time I play it I end up in a happy, comfortable, kinda-tearful haze after it's over. Our Life isn't a drama, or a fantasy, or anything with magic and intrigue. What it is is a small, slice of life narrative that allows you to make it... pretty much everything you could ever want it to be. It's you, your friend (or not, if you choose not to be close to him, but Cove is so sweet, so why wouldn't you), your family, and the people around you that you care for. It's story about growing up with people, none of whom are perfect, and navigating the sometimes-messy but always-warm first few stages of a beautiful, simple life. 

I cannot stress how much writing went into this story. It's soft and gentle, but it's got so much nuance, and depending on the routes you take, can really dive deep into the things that make us tick. It sorts through happy, sad, messy, complex, and sometimes selfish emotions in a way that shows everybody involved growing for the better. You meet an unforgettable cast of people that you truly end up loving once you leave them - but as the ending credits say, "You can come back always." Because... you can. Our Life is always there, and there's always a new nuance for you to check out, a new route to take, a new decision to make. 

It's incredibly inclusive. You can customize yourself in any way you want - gender, sexuality, preferences, body esteem, personality quirks, and anything else you can think of. Even when it's a choice as simple as how to respond to your sister saying good morning, you have half a dozen choices. There are all sorts of characters with all sorts of personality traits and they all feel like someone I might meet at work tomorrow. 

And the cast of romance options is prime, too. Of note, this is most definitely Cove's story. While you can play the story as indifferent to Cove (I never have, so I don't know how it would go), ultimately the story is about the two of you finding each other as children and how you grow up together. Cove is the sweetest boyfriend imaginable, should you choose to walk that road with him, and even if you only choose to be best friends, he's always there for you and never hesitates to tell you what you mean to him. And, should you choose to take that road, the wedding DLC for Cove is super, super sweet. I cried while playing it. 

Derek and Baxter don't have as much and yet, they have more than I'd expect. It's Cove's story, but if you pick up their DLCs, you can have a nice summer with either of the others, with an epilogue for any of them (the Wedding DLC is only for Cove, although your other friends are there). I will note that Derek's route probably has the least romance, which was a little bit disappointing; but at the same time, his DLC dealt a lot with his family - all of whom are charming in their own ways - and I still felt like it was an enjoyable story. And Baxter's... if you wanted drama, pick Baxter. There's heartbreak there, and you can choose to resolve that heartbreak in whatever way you choose. But should you want to see that heartbreak heal, the game delivers in [i]spades[/i] - I just finished it but I have a strong feeling I'm going to go back to read it again tomorrow. Baxter is a messy, messy man, but he's a good man at the core and the game does such an amazing job of navigating the kinds of emotional trauma a person can have.

So, Our Life may not be for everybody, but if you're looking for something feel-good and you like slice of life - or you just need someone to tell you how much you matter to them - pick it up. I don't think you'll regret it - I didn't.

138658062.review:
It was about a year ago when I saw this game on Steam and played it on my potato computer that could barely hold a Google Meeting without burning like a stove. Honestly, I tried this game out on a whim—the summary sounded funny and interesting, and the fact that the MC was fully customizable made this game stand out from the other romance/visual novel games.

Enter the main love interest of the game: Cove Holden. This dude is literally one of the few fictional characters that had me genuinely falling. I think it's mostly because of the fact that you grow up with him; there's a different kind of bond that grows when you go through that. You get to see him as a child, in his most vulnerable and innocent state. You get to see him as a teenager, a young person slowly developing and understanding who they want to be. And you get to see him as a young adult, someone who doesn't want to let go of the things and people that make him happiest. All of this topped with a budding and blooming romance between you and this very boy.

This game feels more than your usual visual novel. The fact that Cove Holden feels so fleshed out, so detailed and planned, makes him feel like an actual person at times. The choices you make in this game feel insignificant at first, but they all still matter nonetheless. Sometimes I regret treating Cove so nicely in my first playthrough, because if I wanted to play this game and treat him badly, it would make me feel like such a bad person.

Cove isn't the only lovable character in this game, of course. The mothers of the MC, the parents of Cove, the friends you make and lose along the way—they all had an impact on me no matter how brief their appearances. The fact that you can now date Derek and Baxter (with the DLCs) could only make me think just how deep their stories really go.

The music and the artstyle, 10/10. Most of the time I play games while playing songs in the background, but the music in this game really makes you immersed; well, I also did play this game at the God-awful hours of 3am, so that's also a factor. But that also makes another point as to why I have nearly 27 hours and counting on this game: I could play this game from 7pm to 3am, non-stop. The urge to find out how and when the MC and Cove will fall in love kept me playing, because I'm a sucker for these tropes and an even worse sucker for confession scenes.

'Our Life: Beginnings & Always' will always be one of (if not) my favourite visual novel games of all time. Major props to anyone and everyone who worked on this game, including the people who gave this game a positive review so that I could be convinced that this game was worth my time. I've played and heard many stories before, and I will in the future, but rest assured that the stories in this game will be remembered in my heart.

The fact that Cove is demi, panromantic, and autistic is such a nice touch too - I rarely ever see games with rep like that with the main love interest <3 and the fact that the player themselves can discover who they are at different stages of life or even know right away what they identify as is a nice touch. It's just super personalised and inclusive and just knocks most other VNs/dating sims out of the park.

I even got the DLC because I was so invested. Definitely a game I will keep coming back to. I recc it to anyone who enjoys dating sims or even just visual novels as a whole, because it's such a cute and wholesome story about growing up <3

[h1]This game is truly a phenomenal piece of work.[h1]
This game allowed me to experience something I never have ever experienced.
A new life I never lived.
as soon as I opened the game and started playing I new I was hooked. Everything from the music to the characters to the writing, it was phenomenal. I seriously enjoyed the main story and the wedding DLC.

138423494.review:
Rarely do recommendations, but:
Amazing game. I was hesitant to begin the genre because of cliche moments, or feeling like things were forced, or poor options/results to my choices... But this game didn't have any of my expected issues.

The dialogue: TONS of options. Your responses affect the game, who returns as friends, or who leaves your life... the game has many references to your past decisions, even in the dlc (I only currently own the wedding dlc, with intent to buy more).

Cove: The game set it up to be however you wanted it to be in regards to him. How shy he is, how assertive... Do you want him making the first move? Or do you want him to let you? It even went as far as allowing you to tweak his personality at the end of each segment of the game if he had become too shy or assertive during his own growth... This leading to you having whatever experience you want.

Inclusiveness: pronoun/gender options, even in wedding scenario. Are you a female, but want to be called a husband at your wedding? Great! However these things are optional and not forced on anyone. The game lets you choose your own comfort with (most of) it, and even change your characters preferences mid game.

In conclusion, I give it a 10/10. 1: For the vastness of the choices. 2: Feeling like those choices mattered. 3:Ease of use, the game was tailored to my personal playthrough. 4:IT'S FREE!!! Even without any DLC, on ONE PLAYTHROUGH I was at over 11 hours, and that's with me skipping a few things the game had because it didn't suit me or my character I was playing as... Then the wedding DLC put me to over 17 hours total!

So go buy the game! And even if you don't plan to use it, buy a DLC and support the creators for giving this insane amount of content for free! I intend to (haven't yet) buy some more of the DLC packs and play it again soon myself!

137996661.review:
Cove Holden is a sweet little cinnamon bun who deserves the world.  This is seriously the most sweet and wholesome games I've played.  After playing, I wanted nothing more than to protect his little pixelated heart! <3
------------------------------------------------------------------------
After having sunk a ridiculous number of hours into this game and all the DLCs, I honestly cannot recommend this game highly enough.  What a ride.  Our Life: Beginnings and Always is an absolute delight.  The story line is slow, comforting, and peaceful, and all the characters are beautifully fleshed out.  Cove and your MC are really the stars of this masterpiece, and unlike other otome I've played, it was so easy to sink into character and get completely immersed into the game and emotionally invested.  The characters and situations are believable, the emotional reactions were fitting, and I loved the number of options you can make throughout the playthroughs.  I loved the amount of detail put into descriptions and callbacks are frankly astonishing - often characters would recall something and mention events from one Moment to another, truly making you feel like you were having a conversation with them.  As for the additional paid DLCs, they are necessary, but they're absolutely worth getting.  The DLCs add a lot of content to the main story line, and if you found yourself loving the characters there, you'll definitely love spending more time with them via the additional Moments.  I very rarely like replaying visual novel type games, but this is a special exception.  The only thing I didn't like about this game is that, like your time in Sunset Bird, it does eventually come to an end.  But unlike real life people who may eventually grow apart from you, you can always revisit Sunset Bird and know that Cove will always be there for you when you need him.  What a beautiful game...what a beautiful life.

137839455.review:
I was honestly a little turned off by the game title, seeing as I am a grown man who is already embarrassed enough about his weakness for dating sims and this one does have a particularly cheesy title. Still, cash-strapped and craving romance, I thought I could give this one a go, and I am so glad I did. Not only has Cove Holden taken a *hold* over my heart, but so has everyone in this game. 
I think the way this game plays out events at different points in time makes it incredibly easy to get attached to everyone. It also makes it very easy to feel nostalgic over how things change. You get just enough time to settle in to one time frame without buying any DLC to feel at home, so the underlying theme of change and growing up hits really hard.
I was pretty unsure about the level of customization at first (and I still feel that it is overdone at some points) but it works really well. I am already happy if an otome game gives me the option to use he/him pronouns, but this game went above and beyond to immerse you. At no point have I have disagreed with what my character was doing or wished I could do something differently, and by the later chapters the experience felt very much catered to me, although I have yet to do a second playthrough to see how different things can turn out. 
Overall, I could not be more positively surprised.

You don't need to buy the DLCs to enjoy this game, as the base game has enough content and replay value. But if you can, I strongly advise you to. They add so much more replay value, and it makes me notice how much the devs care for attention to detail.

137441481.review:
I decided to try this game because I was between games, having just finished my last one and wanting something different and relaxing. I was honestly hesitant to even start playing, I wasn't highly thrilled, but this game really roped me in and gave me a good time which I hadn't expected at all. 

Pros:

- A very relaxing, cozy slice of life game. No stress, really good for a comfort game.
- Nice and well rounded characters
- Ocean theme. Always a plus. (I am a massive ocean lover myself.)
- Nostalgic. Brings back memories of my own childhood. I did not have friends or as much freedom as this but i did live by the ocean. this game was kinda therapeutic in providing childhood experience that felt very realistic with more freedom than i ever had irl and also some buddies. 
- the actual relationship with Cove feels very real.
- The feeling of time naturally moving along at a steady pace was nicely captured 
- Very inclusive of LGBTQ which makes me happy since i myself am a part of this community. In this game there is a demisexual, panromantic, a trans FTM, and gay moms. yay.
- touched on some relatable albeit extremely watered down family issues. 
- I got to give a fish a very obscene name and then everyone was referring to the fish by name
- Generally interesting plot although it drags sometimes and certain things become repetitive 
- characters have arcs and change over time
- You really feel like a part of the story 
- You are allowed a wide array of choices like your height and assigned gender at birth, your pronouns which you can also change later if you want, and who is more initiative of physical affection in the relationship. very in depth!
- actually makes you want the DLC and i havent tried them yet but will one day, since they must be as good as the base game after all
- achievements 
- replayability
- captured the phases of life really well from the care free days of childhood and teen angst and that awkward part when ur a young adult and dont know wtf to do with your life (me)
- extremely wholesome
- good writing but some repetitive terms that get annoying the 100th time youve seen them
- really pretty artwork
- idk if others will agree but i found this to be very immersive. when they wake up early for road trips i could almost feel those sensations and their beach visits made me relive my own from the past which was nice since im far away from the place i consider my home, by the ocean.

cons:

- a little bit overly dramatic. i feel that certain things were made out to be a bigger deal than they needed to be, like the $20 bill, admittedly i never been in this situation but i personally feel like it wasn't that big of a deal despite being a very big main conflict in the story. arguments between characters feel very silly and unnecessary. 
- this is only in cons because i didnt know where else to put it, so not to kink shame but headcanon: Cove has a foot fetish. The way that this dude react to an ankle bracelet is just something else. I found it really funny. 
- this thing can be cringey but um what did u expect ahah this is a guilty pleasure and will be cringey
- sometimes stunted dialog like "ok" when i feel like a lot more could be said
- insufferable banter and bad jokes, but this could be just a me problem 
- so much blushing these people are going to pop a blood vessel

i also realized this is from the same people who made Lake of Voices because of a little mention in the game and i was surprised because thats another really good game and i would recommend u check that out if u havent already 

8/10 extremely enjoyable and has much more pros than cons

a while back i was going through the store and i added many many dating sims to my wishlist, this was one of them. I didn't pay any particular mind to it tho, probably partly because oftentimes free games have proven to be slightly disappointing and all the DLCs felt like a hassle lol
now i was bored and looking for a new VN to play, none of the ones in my library were really calling to me but i didn't really feel like spending money, especially on a game that might end up just sitting in my library because turns out i'm not as interested in it as i thought i'd be... so i peaked at my wishlist and decided to give this a try, figured if i didn't like it anyway it wouldn't be a waste of money at least

now like i said i didn't think much of this game when i added it to my library and honestly at first glance it didn't seem all that interesting for some reason?? maybe because it doesn't have all the flashy out of this world visuals from the other games i'm used to play? i don't know, the plotline seemed basic and boring ?? 
but ,,,,,,,
BOY OH BOY i hadn't been this wrong in a while o.o  this game scratched an itch i've been having for SO long LITERALLY have been looking for a cute, soft, sweet, tender, romance like that for MONTHS (also i have to admit i'm a freakin sucker for the childhood friend love trope) , all the other VNs i play or currently have in my library are kinda too ''out there'', too grand, not real life-ish enough lmao 

ALSO i was shooked cuz i legit spend most of my time in my head making up these random daily life romance stories with an OC of mine named Jamie :'))))  the coincidence that this is the preset name for the MC was absolutely unreal!! and the character customization is SO GOOD seriously it really allowed me to make him pretty much how i imagine him  <3  the trans inclusion also made me sooo freakin happy!! not only that but i LOVE how there's always so many different answers to choose from! lots of games have very black and white, yes or no, this or that type of answers but this game is very flexible 

anyway, i have now bought the DLCs heh but honestly even without them this game is SOOO good like i can't believe it's free! so yeah i was more than happy to throw my money at it <3

in conclusion / TLDR ;
i REALLY misjudged this game, i am absolutely IN. LOVE.  it's so so sooOoooOooo good, so many emotions, i love Cove sooooo much !! My heart <3 :'')))))

136877593.review:
This game was really special and unique for me to play. As a gal currently approaching 30 and only just getting things set up for an autism assessment, this game allowed me to self insert so hard that I was able to see how different I was as a child, struggling with the same kinds of challenges Cove did. I can't really put into words how much this game felt like a big ole warm blanket straight out of the drier. There was a moment during a market scene where the parents leave your character to shop by yourself - and initially I fell back on what my 'masking' would demand- that I be alright with it. That its not a big deal. Gotta people please, gotta fit in. 
But Cove finds your character and is very sweet and genuine- asking if you're really ok. And I wouldn't have been, not really. Crowds freak me out, I've just had to squash that down even if it hurts. Later on Cove is angry on your behalf, and says something I found very powerful and touching: 'Just because Y/N tries to make things a good time no matter what, that doesn't mean you can just leave her out of your plans and expect her to go with it every time.'
Like- ow. You know when you experience something you didn't know you needed? Yeah, that moment was that for me. It was deeply personal. I appreciated it so so much.
So uh yeah - thank you devs. I rec this game for anyone who likes slice of life stuff, especially friends to lovers and fluff. If slice of life stuff bores you then you might find this slow, but personally I really enjoyed this game despite not usually liking the genre. 
10/10

136845433.review: I wouldn't be lying when I say I am absolutely in love with this game. At first, I downloaded it from another site, and honestly it's the first visual novel that I spent countless hours on, not wanting to leave things unfinished. I just kept playing out different scenarios, and it was all with just the /free/ base, there are simply so many things you could be doing, how you're treating Cove (even though it's hard to be indifferent to him, I couldn't bring myself to try that out), what you want from life... It's such a comforting game, especially to those who are a part of lgbt+ community (being able to make your character trans, or be worried about being gay out in public), but not limited to just that. It's good in every way possible. There was a moment I decided to finally get it on steam though, mainly for the purpose of finally trying out the paid content, and I have to be honest- it was the greatest decision of my life. The DLCs (which are honestly so cheap) are absolutely worth it. More stories, meeting characters in a different way, choosing to date Derek, or maybe choosing to marry Cove. All of it is simply amazing and comforting. Great writing that keeps you interested in more and more, choices that actually impact your entire story, customizable mc. There is not a thing I would change. I would absolutely recommend it for anyone who seeks an emotional story, or is simply a sucker for childhood friends to lovers trope! (Although you can choose to simply not have ANY romance in the game and play it out as friends/found-family, which is great too) This game is definitely worth a few hours of your life.

136715195.review:
[h1] Overall: If you are into woke culture, this is perfect for you. If not, skip it. [/h1]

[b] PROS: [/b]
[list]
[*]The characters and overall artwork are fantastic! They are all drawn really well. The CGs are all beautifully drawn as well.
[*]TONS (and I mean tons) of options for the player to make throughout the story. While many of these may not significantly impact the gameplay, I think it feels very immersive and more personable to be able to choose every single thing your character prefers throughout the story. I've never played a VN with so many options.
[*]Generally likable characters all around. 
[*]Choices impact gameplay to a pretty decent extent from what I can tell. They also affect how Cove turns out, although you can choose to alter these either way.
[*]Options to style Cove the way you want! Really neat feature to be able to choose how you want the main love interest to look like throughout the story.
[/list]

[b] CONS: [/b]
[list]
[*]Although you can "customize your character" you never really see your character, except for their arm, so it doesn't really impact much. It would be cool to at least see a bit more of your character in CGs based on what you chose, although I know that might be tougher to code in.
[*]Kind of a bummer that [spoiler] the highschool years were just entirely skipped over--I think that is when the MC and Cove would have mostly connected during, so it felt like a huge jump over things. [/spoiler]
[*]Sometimes Cove acted a little silly for his age at times, [spoiler] like when he would say "Oh my god!" about little things...very dramatic. [/spoiler]
[*]Toward the end things just became very underwhelming and I got bored. I started skipping through a bunch of dialogue without reading. There was nothing to really keep you around by the end. I didn't even really care for Cove much by the end. 
[*]Overall my biggest complaint was how woke this game was. I've played many visual novels, but maybe it's because many of them are foreign and more traditional, but this one was definitely American lol. I know there are a lot of young people into all the woke stuff nowadays, but for a regular person it was just a lot of options to go through when just trying to play as a straight female. 

I kind of rolled my eyes at the amount of woke options for your character, but I think the real turning point for me was when [spoiler] Cove randomly told the MC that he was demisexual and pansexual or something. It honestly didn't even make sense and felt forced. [/spoiler] 

[spoiler] But then randomly at the end, one of their best friends who seemed like a regular girl and had zero signs otherwise, just up and out of nowhere became transgender. And then Cove also randomly was autistic out of nowhere. [/spoiler] It just felt like your typical case of "what can we do to try and add in wokeness?" It is just so forced. If you're gonna do it, at least make it make sense and not seem like you added it in last minute just to appease a group of people. I know this will make some people salty, but for anyone not into the woke culture it's a game I would skip. 

Overall, I'd give it a 6/10 mostly because the art was wonderful, it was fairly relaxing to play and a nice concept, and I managed to make it til the end. I also enjoyed customizing Cove. Unfortunately, it had too much forced wokeness for my personal taste and took away from the immersion. But hey, if that's what you're into then by all means go enjoy it!

136563521.review:
This is a cute, slice of life style visual novel. Your choices matter in the sense that they are remembered by characters - even in later arcs. The will reference something you did as a kid and you'll laugh about it or tease you good-naturedly. There's a lot of care and attention in the details, and honestly this is the kind of game that makes you feel loved. The characters feel real to me, like they really could be your neighbour or your weird childhood friends or memories of a time growing up. Part of that is that the setting for the game aligns really well with the actual timeline in which I grew up, so I feel like this was all stuff I really did or experienced. But also, the way characters grow throughout the years feels very REAL, but not in a depressing way. 

I've played all the DLC for this game (including ones that are currently Patreon only, because yes, I decided to back the project), and while there are a few moments or the odd character I don't personally care for, I think there's a lot here that many people would identify with. Cove is the softest, best boy and I love him to pieces, and it's very friendly towards the LGBTQ+ community. You can make yourself or you can make your dream self, and I think both ways are healing. 

The hardest thing about this game is trying to get the achievement where you are indifferent towards Cove the whole time - probably easier now that there's DLC out for other characters, but that was certainly a TIME when I first did it. But maybe you'll like that too, I dunno!

Anyways, strong recommendation from me for anyone who loves visual novel-type games and a wholesome storyline, whether it be for healing, acceptance or amusement. 10/10 Fantastic game.

136220684.review:
Even though I'm not the target audience, I can't even tell how much I loved this. It is a nostalgic and wholesome story about a childhood friendship (and optional romance) between two neighbour kids who are growing up together in a quiet American beach town. The story is not linear, but consists of "moments" that you can play in any order, such as a day at the beach, a sleepover, doing homework, going to the movies or on a roadtrip (and I wish there were more, including a "step" of when they are 15-16 years old). I recommend to buy all DLCs before starting playing, so you could enjoy all moments in a single playthrough.

You have a lot of freedom, from deciding the appearance and personality of the main characters to lots of choices in conversation options. Some of these choices unlock new chat topics, however no matter what options you select, you cannot "ruin" the story. Just say what your heart says, and enjoy the heartwarming moments. It also touches several important issues, but never in a didactic or overwhelming manner; everything is nice, natural and beautiful in this game.

Last but not least, the visuals and the soundtrack are great as well. Many VNs have too simple or caricaturistic graphics, or dull music that soon starts to get on your nerves. Our Life has none of these flaws; it's perfect in all aspects.

136208725.review: Bought the DLCs almost immediately when I did my first playthrough and I can safely say I do not regret a single cent. The moments in this game is something you could relive again and again despite playing it previously, especially when it comes to Step 2 and/or 3. Those two Steps are ones I'll hold dearly to my heart because Step 2 is just absolutely adorable and Step 3 is rather healing and definitely helps makes me feel like I'm not alone, despite Cove being fictional sdfghjkl. But overall, infinite/10, would recommend everyone to our dear and beloved ocean boy :>

our life: beginnings & always is one of the earliest games I played on steam and despite having completed all of the available free content with the addition of the released dlcs, I come back to it every so often to experience once more those warm memories that I have earned from it. 

everything is so beautifully put together, and the amount of inclusiveness the game offers is something that at the outset caught me off guard and that genuinely made me happy. it was comforting how I was given the possibility to make my own choices based on my preferences without the concern of them affecting negatively the storyline. 

the characters and the environment are portrayed in a way that conveys serenity and solace, and I especially adore the softness and the singularity of each character. every aspect of this visual novel, from the graphics to the music and the plot itself, was beyond mesmerizing and without so much as a modicum of effort, it completely charmed me.

those gentle moments spent in the small town of sunset bird alongside the most supportive and affectionate family I could ever hope for with the company of such endearing friends belong to a journey that I will forever cherish.

135696548.review:
I, as a general rule of thumb, don't write reviews for video games often. When I do write a review, it's because that video game has touched my life in some way that makes it an unforgettable experience for me.

Is Our Life: Beginnings & Always by any stretch of imagination, the most polished looking, immersive, artistic dating sim/visual novel I've ever played?... Well No. But not every game needs to be top of the line or highly funded.

What this game is though, was a chance to heal my inner child. As a queer adult, I often get sentimental over all the lost time I'll never get back in my childhood growing up. All the friends I couldn't make because I lived in the middle of nowhere, all the great loves I missed out on because of parents who'd rather see me at a camp. The families and friends in this game, however, reminded me of what could have been, and through that I've been able to work through some emotions I've been struggling with since I turned 21 years ago.

Not to mention, Cove, while very different from myself, was also much the same as I was growing up. It didn't hit me till I ran it through a second time, this time with DLCs, but when I realized it, it was sort of serendipitous. Walking away from the game I've come to re-evaluate what it means to love, and to be loved.

That's why I'm leaving this little note of a review. The story contained within this game, while not perfect, is healing. Especially if you're like me, and feel like you've lost time.

Our Life is one of the most moving games I've ever played, and an east 10/10 for me. 

My wife and I played it together last summer (off her account) and it dug it's claws in me and wont let go. The characters are wonderful, the setting is comforting, and the music is serene and idyllic. You create your own character, and from the age of 8, grow up along side Cove Holden as you both tackle the challenges of life every 5 summers until adult hood.

While it might not be the most "exciting" experience for some gamers, I would recommend this to any one. The joy of hanging out with Cove and other friends, paired with the beautiful art and music, evokes a nostalgia for people and places never met or seen, and is one of the very *very* few games (Hell, media in general.) I've ever played that actually made me happy cry. 

If you're on the fence on this one, don't be. You will not regret spending time in Sunset Bird alongside Cove.
