135110318.review:
I'm not sure why I haven't written anything for Our Life earlier. maybe it's because I treasure this game so much that I was afraid I wouldn't know how to describe how much it means to me. 

I wasn't looking for it when I first found it, but it seemed like a game that would keep me busy for an hour or so and that's why I decided to download it. 

Cove Holden quickly became a comfort character for me. he is just... the ultimate sweetheart. his friendship with the mc (if we go for the we-are-just-friends route) reminds me a lot of the one I had with a childhood friend of mine. she lived across the street from me and we used to do everything together, even boring stuff like go to the market 'cause my mom wanted me to buy something. it was nice to remember how it is to have such a strong bond with someone.

not long after playing the base game for the first time, I recommended it to my best friend. she got attached to Cove just as much as I did. our love for him and Our Life became another thing that we have in common and that we can spend hours talking about. we've had so many discussions about the characters and the story, of how this game approaches some serious and important topics we haven't seen in other VNs.

Our Life is one of my comfort games, a place I know I can always go to whenever I'm feeling down. a game that brought me some nostalgic memories of childhood and straightened the bond between my best friend and I. we know that, whatever may happen, Cove (and Derek. and soon, Baxter too) will be waiting for us with open arms.

134997974.review:
This game really is the sweetest and most amazing game I've played I think ever. I'm actually struggling to come up with words to describe how great this game is.

First of all, I love how accepting and open this game is to pretty much everyone. The MC can be a girl, or a boy, or they/them. You can also later choose to change gender, how you see your body, the way you deal with things... And your family and friends are all accepting and nice. Sure, it might be a bit of a fairytale but it has such a positive message.
You can also choose which gender you like, if you're comfortable with touching Cove and him touching you or not at all, how far you want to take things... You really are completely in control.

The amount of choices also is amazing. You really are part of the story and don't just spend minutes upon minutes just reading dialogues before finally being able to choose something again.
The art is very nice as well. Every stage the characters get older and I loved seeing how the moms get some gray hairs and how the house changes for example. It's subtle but strongly done.

What I loved most though was how you can completely shape the relationship between you and Cove. I myself love romance, hugging, touching but also just being very close to each other. So my relationship with him was basically being glued hip to hip. And I'll tell you, when the characters go to college and have to separate for a time, I really can't remember the last time I cried so hard. It seemed a crime to separate them at that point and I hated the thought of it.
The story has a lot of moments where the characters remember their past and are thankful for each other. I will admit, in the end at some points I got a bit tired of it since it felt like a lot of the same thing. But I was still just looking with a big goofy grin on my face and thinking how adorable they are together.

1 thing I did not like is how you never actually see the MC. You can change the way she (/he/they) looks but that's only her face and you never see sprites with her (I'm just gonna go with the MC being a her since this was the case with me). I would've loved it if there were a few, like 4 or 5 pictures or even just 1 where they get married, where you see Cove and the MC together. I understand this would've been difficult with all the things you can choose but another game I played (Tailor tales) does this by offering some basic colours for hair/eyes. You can still change a lot more but the main image only offers those choices.

But really, that's just nitpicking at this point. This really is the most beautiful, cute, sweet and amazing game and that they ask so little money for it is a crime in my opinion. It deserves so much more love and attention.

134988091.review: there is a different flavor to this game. growing up with cove from childhood and seeing him become such an individual was fun! plus having the option to be best friends (with none of that bad ending or rejection crap. you can just chill with your bestie homie cove and grow up with him) or together. being together and choosing not to marry or getting married (via dlc but u can still be engaged to him during adulthood if u romance him) is great! being able to customize your appearance, identity and the variety of options for the wedding dlc for who you are felt like a breath of fresh air in very usually catered to cis female audiences and the character is usually pale with brown hair.. AND it's free?! every character in the game didn't just feel like side characters who are there to fill some space in the plot and are actually their own people.. i loved kyra, cliff, and liz the most.. honestly it's just great as kind of a growing up with a soul mate type game. not just in a romantic sense. shout out to gb.. all and all lovely game! for it being free it has a lot to offer story and event and cg wise. my only complaint is that the artstyle was somewhat inconsistent at times and i wish there were a bit more cgs even with the extra dlc it felt like not much to be honest. although for a free game i understand why they couldn't do a lot.. get our life NOW!!

134884155.review:
"Our Life: Beginnings and Always" is an interactive graphic novel that I am thoroughly enjoying. The storyline is entertaining and has kept me engaged throughout my gameplay. Although the characters can seem a little too perfect at times, I find them interesting and well-crafted. Cove, in particular, is a character that I feel could use a little less sadness, but I understand that it may be part of their character arc.

As I am only in the second chapter, I am excited to see how the characters will develop over time. I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys interactive graphic novels and likes to follow the growth and evolution of characters. The strong point of this game is the well-written character development.

Overall, "Our Life: Beginnings and Always" is an engaging and enjoyable interactive graphic novel. Despite some minor flaws, it has kept me interested and invested in the characters' stories. I highly recommend it to anyone who is looking for a game with a strong storyline and well-crafted characters.

134700522.review:
[h1] Whimsical, peaceful and wholesome visual novel[/h1]
This game will wrap you in a blanket and pat your head. It takes player agency, player opinions/choices, diversity representation and wholesomeness very seriously without becoming too paedagogical (mostly). The character cast is lovely (the star of it all is Cove, naturally) and the players truly feels like they belong, it's so immersive. 
The creators beautifully crafted how it feels to grow up and I was especially impressed with the first life stage as a 8-year old. It was truthful to a child's worldview without being childish or on-the-nose.
I have to mention though that this has a specifically US-centred (Californian) vision of what it feels like to grow up - not in a bad or obnoxious way at all, it's just that a few little details struck me (as a European) as odd. This doesn't take away from the experience at all though! 
It's grand, it's lovely, it is blissfully creep- and yandere-free and it's a breath of fresh air for the genre.
Don't hesitate to get the DLCs either. 
This game was made with so much love and it shows. 
If you like the slice-of-life genre at all (romance optional, but great if chosen), you will adore this.

134402859.review:
This game is free therapy. <- this is the description of an "Our Life" playlist on spotify and I smiled so much when I saw it, because it is very true. 

This game is amazing not only because of the endless meaningful messages it sends but overall because it leaves the player with a very positive feeling. "You are okay, just as you are". There is so much love for the MC - and every choice is okay. There is no bad ending. 

A definitive must play for everyone who likes visual novels. The music, the dialogues, the pacing is just perfect. 

The amount of choices and settings you can choose from is incredible - your room design, your hobbies, your sandwich, your crepe choice, your fudge choice, your favorite ice cream, how your character looks, including details like how you feel about your looks.... its endless - it even includes vegan/vegetarian or lactose intolerant dialogue and the game / characters around you remember it all the time (!) through the whole gameplay and is very open minded about everything. 
I was so happy about this detail because irl I often don't get support for this but am criticized for being "such a picky eater". 

And as a nice side effect I learned a lot while playing this game and had so much fun. This is why I think everyone should try it. 

One thing especially surprised me and was very well done: I have never seen a romance VN before where you can actually chose between 3 ways of "how should the LI and the MC handle intimacy?" 

The only game I saw a choice like it before was "When the Night Comes" and there you had a choice every single time there was touching, a kiss ore more and the game asked how you wanted that to play out (or if not). 

How the authors handled this here is incredible and I love details like this that include the player freedom and the overall "feel good and relax, this here is a safe place" feeling of this game so much.

Thank you dear developers for this gem! It helped me relaxing when I needed it the most.

134069158.review:
This isn't an easy choice, but if I have to... I [b]would not[/b] recommend this game, unfortunately.

The Good:

- There are quite a few genuinely sweet moments that literally had me clutching my chest
- There are a few good supporting characters that are quite interesting and even funny
- The story is good enough that I finished it (as you can see), so there's something to it
- The writing itself is well done, from a literary perspective.
- If you use the Cove Creator, you can modify him to be more to your liking (as his default personality is horrendous but I'll get to that later)


The Bad:

- This game is toothless, spineless, sexless, mealy-mouthed... all those adjectives and more. It is just so so so bland. As someone who normally plays 18+ otome games and reads a lot of adult fiction, this was, at times, torture to get through. 
  ► The game seems to be actively afraid of anything related to sex or intimacy beyond what middle schoolers will do behind the bleachers (aka - just... kissing). This is fine for the younger stages of the game, but once you reach 18 and beyond, it becomes ridiculous to the point of being a huge distraction. Most grown adults (especially 18 year olds!) don't act like this. Which brings me to my next point...

- The universe this takes place in is very Truman Show-like. It does not exist in any reality I'm aware of, yet  pretends it does by referencing our pop culture and whatnot. It is such a picture-perfect fantasy of a place that it, again, becomes a distraction.  Everyone is filthy rich with seemingly unlimited time and income. Nothing ever goes wrong and nothing bad ever happens; the most serious conflict I can remember is two 18 year olds having a sleepover misunderstanding that was resolved in 2 minutes. 
  ► I kept getting sidetracked and ranting to friends about how nothing in this world made sense (a bunch of 18 year olds go on a boat party and are all too afraid to drink alcohol... right...). It's not like Animal Crossing, which is very clearly hyper-stylized and operates on cartoon logic, and its cutesy fantasy land can be forgiven. This uses hyper-realistic backgrounds, references currents events of our world, and yet is nothing like it. It's very very jarring. There is something so unsettling about how everyone is just so [i]nice[/i] and even the "mean" characters are actually just so [i]nice[/i] after a conversation or two. 
  ► There's a difference between escapism and dystopia and this game leans into the latter.

- Cove. COVE. COOOOOOOVE. Holy sh!t. I don't know what they were thinking with this LI. At first, I liked him and felt bad for him, and I find his design in general to be very good and appealing, but I realized over time that I actually started to hate and resent him, which has never happened to me before in all my years of playing otome games with all kinds of trash LIs. By the time I got to the final step, I was actually upset that there was no option for me to turn down the marriage proposal, which is WILD for me to say for an otome game. 
  ► He is just so so whiny, needy, spineless... everything upsets him, everything throws him for a loop, everything makes him freak out in some way shape or form. It's exhausting and deeply unattractive in a LI. Even when, in the last step, he's much friendlier and gregarious, he STILL gets flustered by the dumbest sh!t. It's unreal. 
  ► I also need to point out that Cove is, miraculously, a [b]much better character as long as you never pursue him romantically,[/b] which is also WIIIIILD for an otome game. I tried a friendship route with him out of curiosity and I could not believe how much more interesting and mature he was when he was just your friend. WHERE HAD THAT COVE BEEN?? When you are on a romantic route with him, he's a whiny, sobbing mess; he literally refuses to sleep in the same bed as you, despite the fact that you've basically been dating since you were 8. It's a whole argument and ordeal. But when you're just bros? I asked him to share a bed and he's just like "Yea, sure!" in two seconds flat, no issue. ??? THAT is the Cove I would have been interested in marrying, not the one you end up with. It's so bizarre that it almost feels like a bug.

- Customization seems to do nothing other than to change your skin in certain CGs. It would be nice if the player could at least have a little sprite with different reactions in the dialogue box.

- Some of the CGs are unbelievably gorgeous (the one where he's sitting in the window staring at you literally made me gasp because of how good it looked) and others are horrendous and completely take you out of the story. I don't know why they couldn't maintain CG quality.

So, yeah. Lotta negs, here. This probably sounds like I am unfairly flaming the game or something, but I truly did want to like it. I love otome games, especially ones written in second person, which are difficult too find. I'm genuinely bummed this didn't work for me.

133683535.review:
I have played close to two dozen visual novels at this point, and hands down this is still my my favorite. Our Life offers players more freedom of choice than any other visual novel I have encountered. Which not only encourages players to select authentic answers, which encourages immersion, but makes this visual novel incredibly replayable.

 The overall story and events may stay the same, but the beauty and fun is in the details with game. But, like I mentioned this may be more fun to replay for detail-oriented players than big picture players. 

It was the first VN I played that allowed character customization. Even though you do not get to see the MC, since it is first person, the writing considers the selections players made. That is also true in regards of all the little decisions you make along the way. So much care and consideration went into the writing and creation of this game.

The settings are wonderful. The cast of characters is endearing. The music is calming. Big shout out to Fat Bard for creating such a good song for the game. DCL has been released for this game since it was released.

The only three areas which I feel this game could improve are that I feel like more characters should have portraits. Even when characters play a minor role in the story. I would love a face to the name or role they are fulfilling. That would further help immersion. This is most noticeable if you are play the Cove Wedding Special DLC. 

The other small area the game could improve in are the special art images, Which I believe unlock once you buy the original game, so you can see them throughout your story then. The art in those images is not of the same quality as the art elsewhere in the game. I do understand why that is. But none the less I feel I should mention it.

Lastly, this is just a detail. The way the fireflies are animated in the backgrounds in certain summer evening scenes. They are moving yellow orbs. I do not remember if they fade and reappear as they move at all. It has been a few months since I played this.They do not change in size as they move. Which makes their movement flat. Just adjusting those would help a lot with the illusion of depth. Also if the opaque yellow section was smaller, and they have a larger section with a lower level opacity yellow surrounding the opaque section, with a soft/feathered edge, that would help too. 

I am only listing these minor issues due to my love and respect of the game. I want to be honest so I can do what I can to help the creators do even better in the future. I am looking forward to their future projects. :) As I said at the start, this is my favorite visual novel by a mile.

I hold it in higher regard than ones created by big companies which tend to rest on their laurels of set game mechanics, fancy art, and big name voice actors to carry their games. Rather than actually trying create visual novels that will satisfy players better. For which I blame the management and big shot callers at such companies rather than the people who directly create the visual novels. 

So major props to all the indie companies and creators using their freedom to create more satisfying visual novels to play. They are the ones who are the future of visual novels. So please do support them. Thanks for your hard work making this game. And thank you for you time for all who read this. :)

133390492.review:
I adore this game, there's so much to like.

Inclusivity: Extremely inclusive gender-wise, pronoun-wise, eating habits and preferences (ex. vegan), the characters respect your choices no matter who you are

Customization: Great! Really feels like you can put a lot into your character. From their gender to their style to things like if they want a crepe. You get to choose how much initiative Cove (and Derek if you got the DLC like me) have, what Cove wears, his personality (if he's warmer or if he's sporty, etc.). You also don't even need to end up with anyone, you can go through friendship routes too, especially since you get to choose any sexuality and romantic preferences for your character! I do wish we could see our character while we're speaking, I always forget what they look like and get surprised after each step!

Characters: I love every character in this game! The MC's moms are both AMAZING I love both of them greatly, their sister Liz is quite charming in her own snarky way, the MC's cousin Lee is a really great female friend to have and is brimming with positive energy. Shiloh and Jeremy make a return from XOXO Droplets (& Blood Droplets haha) and ohhh boy having two members of the Jerk Squad in a warm little game like this was very amusing! (Side note: Jeremy's parents did him dirty with that bowl cut.). Now for the prime character: Cove. Amazing, fantastic, growing up with him you get to see his struggles, his flaws, his fears, and how our friend grows from it all. He's not afraid to be emotional and honest and has a passion for all things Ocean! Cove is a genuinely well-developed character whether you're romancing him, befriending him, or treating him like a stranger.

You also get to meet Derek, a non-resident of Sunset Bay who comes to visit on his dad's business trips who has a business with Cove's father (another well-rounded, funny, yet tactless character). He's an adorable, responsible, fun-loving guy. And if you're like me, you might end up adoring him enough to get his DLC which is TOTALLY WORTH IT! I love seeing more about his family who are all charming and chaotic (especially a certain little trouble maker.). Derek is an adorable sporty-shorty who puts too much pressure on himself and I adore him.

Vibe: The overall vibe is very warm and accepting, the art has a soft nature to it as does the music and every character is friendly (aside from Jeremy lol). You grow up and face hardships, but its all worth it at Sunset Bay.

Great game, free, inclusive, and very re-playable.

I've been playing date sims and otomes for years, and it's the first time I've played one so heartwarming. Wholesome, sweet and fulfilling. I Love it, with capital L.

Plus, the art is beautiful as well as the music, the writing is amazing and the amount of attention to details this game has left me surprised in a good way. It was adorable to see my character's freckled-hand in the few illustrations that showed some amount of MC content, or when the characters remembered my favorite flower, my heigh or what I chose in certain decisions. A game totally worth paying for and playing the +65 hours I have (and counting).

132545822.review:
TLDR: The art is beautiful, the characters are crafted with love and care. The little choices you make can come back later in 'life' as little anecdotes or even big milestones, all woven together to create a wonderful story. If you can, I encourage you to get the DLCs, they add a lot of great content. 

And if you want my (almost) full thoughts, here you go:

Phew... Where do I begin? I've had the game a week almost hour for hour and oh boy... I may or may have not sacrificed both many responsibilities and much sleep to Sunset Bird, Cove Holden and Derek Suarez (and soon Baxter Ward!) in this short time-frame. Do I regret it though? Oh hell no. It's been worth every tired, squinty-eyed blink and panicked 'oh shoot I gotta do this'. 

I initially picked the game up because it was in the LGBT+ tag and it wasn't a 'woohoo sexy wowie bewbs!' game that steam insists on shoving down my throat (get better, steam). I wanted something nice and light y'know? Browsing curiously in search of kindred spirits. "Huh, a visual novel game?" I remember thinking, "Okay, I've never liked them much, but it's free and it probably won't take long. And if I like it enough I can support the devs by buying a DLC or two." HA! Oh how naïve I was! 

Oh boy.

Guys, gals, and pals, I bought all the DLCs within the first 5 hours and have since spent almost 87 hours of my life on this game and have every intention of spending many more on it, although hopefully at a slower rhythm than the unwavering single-minded devotion I've had until now. I can assure you, it's not short, and it's very replayable (I'm on my third(?) full playthrough, with added time for just replaying some moments and steps differently). It IS however light-hearted, impossibly gentle, and the exact kind of relaxing I was looking for. 

It was thrilling to find out I could not only pick neutral pronouns, but got to change them at the beginning of every step if I so desired, and then throughout the game even got to pick assigned gender and how I wanted my MC to present, the clothes they would wear when the occasion called for it, surgeries and HRT they may have been through... 

The game offers countless possibilities to explore oneself, which I think is absolutely fantastic; for people still in the closet, for people searching themselves, for people who know themselves and what they enjoy inside out, the thing we have in common is that we'll all have a nice time, whether we're playing as a completely original character of our own imagining, or projecting ourselves into the story. It's easy; there's no pressure, you do it however you want as many ways as you want, as many times as you want. The game respects boundaries as much as possible, giving options all the way to your choice of greeting people, old and new.

The only real 'downsides' I can find is that I would like to be able to have even more fluffy and cuddly little moments, as well as the option of poly. 

I am so very very fond of this game, it's a true labour of love, and am so glad I picked it up. This has quite honestly been exactly what I needed lately; a little escape to a peaceful place. 

Highly recommend, Cove/10

131959008.review:
I think a lot of reviews have already laid out the good things about this game, so I won't bother giving all the things I thought were great. I'll just say that the customization you feel as the player is spectacular. That's the big thing I'd like to draw attention to. In many romance games, the MC usually has a set composure with a LITTLE variation, but in Our Life, we be kind or mean, in love or not, sassy or sweet, etc. The options are diverse enough to where (I think) many people will get different routes. 

I mean yes there are variations that align closely, but almost no route will be 100% alike. For example, if you choose to skip a scene during childhood, you won't get the choice to add that charm to your phone in adolescence. Small details like that make the experience a little different each time.

131839805.review: This is my favorite visual novel I've ever played. Very LGBTQ+ friendly and inclusive. You can customize the main character (you) almost completely. Can be a romance novel if you want it to be, but can also choose to just have the love interest be your friend. There are some heavier topics like divorce, bullying and body image issues, but it is not touched on in depth unless you pry. The characters are interesting and unique. The setting/town is very nostalgic, the environment feels very safe and lighthearted. The base game is completely free, but I bought all of the DLC for the extra scenes and extra moments. It was completely worth it. You get a lot more attached to the characters as you go on, as you and the people around you get older throughout the years. There are very bittersweet moments while you grow up in game, which do nod back to real life and how relationships can change over time. The art style is beautifully well made, very pleasant to look at. The music is also amazing to listen to. The entire soundtrack I find myself coming back to time and time again as it gets stuck in my frequently and overall is very pleasant. I don't have many complaints about this game at all, but one of the things I don't like is how short it is. It took me about 4 hours to get through the entire base game. If you have DLC it's much longer. Overall a wonderful game if you want a heartwarming, nostalgic, bittersweet coming of age romance that expands throughout the years. 9.5/10.

131787217.review:
I don't own any DLC, but I still feel like I had a satisfying time with this game. I'll probably come back to it when the Baxter DLC comes out, so I can do a full playthrough with every memory unlocked.

It's not challenging in any way, deliberately so. You never have to really agonize about your decisions - with very rare exception, decisions are mostly about self-expression and deciding what sorts of scenes you want to see, rather than affecting the world around you. I didn't have to make decisions that led to my character being bad at surfing, I just decided, when the game asked, that my character was bad at surfing, because that felt right for the sort of character I was playing.

 It's not something I find fun, exactly, but it's... Comfortable. Reading these scenes makes me feel like I'm experiencing a happy childhood, and I'm glad I had this experience.

I felt surprisingly accommodated playing as an aro character. I haven't experienced any of the romance in this game, so I can't say whether it's any good, but playing an Aro protagonist I felt like the friendships my character forged were well-written and - well, comfortable.

tl;dr: comfy.

131223340.review:
Review Contains: Game play/Inclusive/Characters

It heals the heart, the soul, and the inner child.

I stumbled across this game a while back before any of the DLC's were available. I didn't think much of it, but then again it was the first game I've ever downloaded via Steam. I was surprised that I spend 24 HOURS playing through Cove's (non-DLC) routes and I fell in love with his character. Not only is he fully flushed out as a character (pros and cons - gotta love them) but there are choices that MATTER. OUR choices MATTER and they don't have to be paid for! 

GAME PLAY
If you have the chance to get the DLC content, I admit it's very--VERY worth it. The developers have DLC content for each stage and then the final stage (which is the wedding). Each patch has at least an hours worth of content because there are additional stories you are free to explore or not explore. Memories you can make or skip -- I would not recommend skipping them though because once a memory is started it can't be stopped and once you go on to the next stage you can't go back (unless you saved). Also if you skip memories, you won't be able to make more personalized choices in the game. The DLC content is sprinkled with little moments that Cove will remember going into the next stages, i.e. if you told Cove your favorite flower is the peony, in the wedding DLC he's going to want you to have peonies. BUT I will say that this works even without the DLC content, you won't get a half-baked Cove Holden in the free play. 

INCLUSIVE
I spent so many hours (24) playing through the free version of this game testing different outcomes. What would it be like if I played this stage (stage 1 is where you and Cove are kids) in my childhood mindset? What would it be like if I went with my instincts now? The choices, at least for me, changed. There are options to change Cove and customize him however you might like, personality and looks wise, but I think there's something special about how YOUR choices affect his personality in each stage. The save section is one of the most valuable pieces (MVP?) in the game because you don't have to backtrack so far if you want to change a certain outcome.

There are 3 stages in the free play: childhood, early teen, and late teen. In each section you decide how you want to navigate your life. There are so many options and I don't want to spoil anything so here's a great example. Sometime between early and late teen (stages 2 and 3) you get to decide how you view yourself. Are you tall or short? Do you feel secure about that? Are you a vegetarian or pescatarian? How are you in your sexual orientation? What are your long-term goals and are you feeling nervous about the future? All of these questions (and more) are yours to explore as you play through the game. Not only are these very personal and immersive questions that make you feel as if you're really part of the game, but these are moments that make you feel heard if not seen.

CHARACTERS
Cove, for all intents and purposes, is a cinnamon roll who needs a hug. He's a character who I didn't expect to care for so deeply (I ended up buying all the extension packs and I have no regrets -- but you don't need to do this to fall in love with him). He plays the roll of that neighbor kid you grow up next to and you get to decide how much/little you want him in your life. He can be your childhood sweetheart (Taylor Swift?) or he can be your best friend and greatest ally. He can even be the kid you grew up next to, no obligations or anything. Because of how the game is structured through stages, you ultimately get to decide.

The game, for the most part, is centered around you, Cove, family, and friends. As I mentioned earlier, it's a game that heals the heart and soul because I'm pretty sure everyone's got a little something they wished they could've done in the past (or maybe future if you're younger) that they wished could've happened -- in a realistic sense of course. You get the chance to live vicariously through your character. Between the family dynamics of your moms (yes there are two) and your friends (because it's not ALL about Cove), I got to experience what it would be like to be in different supportive environments. It also heals the inner child because I was also able to play the mischievous younger sibling for once. I didn't always have to make that mature decision, even if I wanted to do something else impulsively. Here, you can do that but it won't change the way your family or friends view you (not in a negative sense). Or if you want to play that mature character, you can totally do that too, again the affection from the other supporting characters aren't conditional.

Then here comes Derek! I ADORE Derek Suarez, you get to see him in stage 2 and from small snippets it's really cute to see the boy have a crush on you. Sorry to say though, that if you don't have Derek's special DLC then you won't see him much after stage 2. Free play Derek isn't around as often as I wished he were, but I had enough of his character to want more. When his DLC came out, I did buy it and I have no regrets. This is where the story can become EVEN MORE interesting. Derek has a crush on you, and it's pretty hard to miss. However, when you get into his DLC content you realize there's so much more to the short kid with green eyes. I won't spoil anything about Derek because if you decide to pick up his DLC, then you've dedicated yourself to learning more about him. I already have the wedding DLC and got it before Derek's, but once I downloaded Derek's I also found out that he's got a stage after stage 3 where you are both adults. I'm not sure if you get this stage with Derek's DLC but I'm taking a wild guess it's a yes since Derek pops up in stage 2 and this final stage where you are adults. In this last stage you make big kid decisions and decide what you want at the very end -- is it marriage or is it just friendship? You pick.

The hard part is choosing between which one you want though! Even though you don't have to go the romantic route with either of the boys (Cove/Derek) you certainly can. I haven't tried doing anything like having a crush on both of them at the same time, yet, but whatever you decide they will both be respectful about it. Even if you get Derek's DLC you don't have to choose to want Derek romantically at all, he's a solid friend just like Cove. However it does get difficult because they're both so endearing. 

Baxter (the third and final prospect) comes at stage 3, but just like free play Derek you won't get much of him until the developers come out with his DLC (and I'm patiently waiting). He does pop up in the wedding DLC and Derek's DLC (in stage 2), which is a nice surprise but there's not much about him to really say. He is interesting though, I will say that (again patiently waiting).

CONCLUSION
I could go into so much more detail about this game, but if you've already made it this far then you should try out the free version! I emphasize this so much because I'm not the type to pay for games unless I'm really dedicated (Mystic Messenger/My Child Lebensborn), and I found that this has made it on to that list of never delete ever. Even without the DLC content, I still love the game and I'm sure that if you give it a fair shot then you will too.

131197827.review:
+++ The writing is extremely well done. Every character felt like a real person, the problems, situations, emotions are so... human and real. It's definitely one of the best written visual novel games I've ever played.

++ Loads of choices for each situation. Seems to average at about 6 choices per situation on what to do or say.

+ Handles sensitive topics like [spoiler]gender and divorce[/spoiler] extremely well.

+/- As a straight male, I felt like I wasn't the target audience for this game. I was frequently presented with choices and situations to get romantic with Cove, [spoiler]Derek, or Baxter[/spoiler]. There are no female characters you have the choice of being romantic towards. I didn't realise this until about 1/4 through the game, and at that point I decided to keep playing for the good story. Luckily you can play the entire game at the "friend" level, and it "mostly" respects your choice, apart from the occasional "are you sure you don't want to be gay?" situation.

- I only started buying the DLC during Step 2, but the DLC assumes you've bought the DLC for all previous steps, and it was very confusing because I had no idea what the characters were talking about.

- The choices are not very "deep". There are references, jokes, etc, to past choices, but I didn't feel like anything I did had a dramatic impact outside the individual "Moment". You still end up having access to every Moment, and each Moment will still follow the same general direction.

-- You never really leave the main town outside of special occasions, almost everything happens within the same few locations ([spoiler]your house, Cove's house, the steets, the hill, the beach covers 90% of the Moments[/spoiler]). By the time it hit Step 3 [spoiler]and everyone's an adult coming back to town, and we're wandering the streets, and going to the playground AGAIN,[/spoiler] it felt kind of contrived? Like why can't we hang out at school? Have classroom interactions? Resolve bullying situations? Study at university together? Handle work life balance? Overseas trip to the [spoiler]Philippines[/spoiler]? [spoiler]The struggles of moving in and living together? (if you're into that thing)[/spoiler] The game almost feels "scared" to leave it's comfort zone, to the detrement of the narrative.

Overall, this game is definitely worth playing, even if it did cost money. But it's free so you don't have an excuse.

130609712.review:
TL;DR: If you are looking for a LGBTQ+ game with great art, amazing music and an incredible story you should definitely try out this game!

This review might contain spoilers so be advised

I started playing this game about a year and a bit ago. As a gay man it is quite hard for me to find LGBTQ+ games that are both fun, fluffy and don't portray my existence as taboo. This game is exactly what I needed. 

You play as the adoptive child of a lesbian couple who live in pretty much a quiet middle of nowhere type of neighbourhood. The journey starts when you are 8 and you can customise pretty much everything about yourself from your name, your pronouns, your physical appearance, whatever scars you might have, whether you wear a hijab or not and the types of clothing and accessories you prefer. It provides quite a bit of diversity (although of course as a white man I can only judge that from my narrow perspective). The customisation continues in step 2 (when you are 13) and step 3 (when you are 18) and you are allowed to change every aspect of yourself including your pronouns at any point between each step.

As for the story, Cove a young boy moves into the neighbourhood with his dad and you get to grow alongside him. There is not much that can be said without spoiling the contents of the game however there is a wide variety of choices on your answers (most of which affect the story later on). Before each step starts you can choose your feelings towards Cove so if you'd prefer playing this game just by nurturing a friendship with him that is possible. You can also choose to customise Cove in full (appearance and personality).

The art is stunning. The only issues I have in terms of it (and this is where you might get spoiled so be advised) is that in step 3 Derek and Terry seem to be hastily made. Specifically their voices. There is nothing I can directly point out as wrong per se they just seem to be out of place. Their voices sound as if they are put through a voice changer to sound deeper and personally it felt weird to hear.

Other than that, the game itself is a masterpiece in my eyes and I keep coming back to it no matter how many times I've played it through. I wish there was more to it because I can never get enough of Cove!!

While I will admit that I didn't care too much for Cove during most of my runs of the game (still waiting on that Baxter DLC, he rules; Derek was pretty cool too), I do love the replay value this VN has by virtue of relationship strength with characters, Cove's variable changes across Steps based on your playstyle and most importantly, the way you can customize the player character. I've had loads of fun playing as a complete jerkoff in different flavors, although not so much in how little that ultimately affects overall story progression. This works very well within Steps, however; no problem there. It seems like the only things that really matter here are your approach to Cove and your relationship status with him, as side characters sometimes don't seem to remember what you've said or done to them. Probably a caveat of the feel-good angle this VN is working with, but it doesn't really work for me. Mind you, this could also just be a target audience issue lol

DLC is totally worth it; it gives you more opportunities to experiment with your character's choices and seeing how they play out in other scenarios within the same Step. Additional scenarios also grant you more opportunities to see if you want to leave things the way they are with Cove or maybe bump it up to Fond/Crush/Love in future Steps. With more scenarios, I ended up especially loving Lee from Step 2, Terri and Baxter from Step 3, the entire Suarez family (cop that Derek DLC, it's so worth it wtf) and one "secret" character from Derek's route. Hell, I even started to come around with Jeremy in the Step 3 DLC. Took my constant abuse of him in past Steps in stride lmao, god bless

The gripes I have with Beginnings and Always appear to be rectified in the Now and Forever demo along with the addition of incredible features; I've been bleeding said demo for everything it has, I absolutely can't wait to grow alongside Tamarack, get into tussles with Qiu's gang and learn more about the player character's mother. I also do appreciate how characters are more willing to disagree with you and assert themselves as they do in XOXO Droplets, which I would love to play but can't because I absolutely despise the player character in that one.

But again, Cove starts to really annoy me in Step 3 onward with his near disregard for relationship status; you can be as disinterested, aromantically fond, intimately interested or deeply committed to him as you want and he'll almost certainly react the exact same way with a strange sense of reverence. His actions make a lot more sense if you're at the Crush or Love level, but Fond could work if you intend on dating Cove in future Steps in a friends-to-lovers sort of way.

Again, there are myriad ways to play Beginnings and Always thanks to robust customization in comparison to other dating sims and VNs like it. Your choices don't always make a difference and the roster of dateables isn't the best at the moment, but the sheer amount of story and development present in this game is hard to stay neutral about. So much went into developing these characters, that much I can tell. The base game is pretty good, but beware: you get one DLC pack and you're gonna want to get the rest of them once you see how expansive this installment of Our Life can get. Give this a try, it's a very interesting experience for sure.

130468531.review:
1000000000000000/10
        Look, I really have no complaints when it comes to this game. I have 30 hours on it for a reason and have replayed the whole game multiple times. It's a very cute, feel-good game where you can pursue friendship, romance, or neither with the absolute sweetheart known as Cove Holden.
	In the game, you play as a main character you can customize the name, pronouns, look, and personality of. That means you could play as you, or a random character you made up. The game is divided into 4 steps, each showing the characters at a different age and each having unique game-play. And, you can unlock even more stuff for each step with the DLC (I recommended it, it's super fun and cheap) plus an entirely new step where you can plan your and Cove’s wedding (if you decide to have a romantic relationship with him.)
	The game is really chill and cute, without much conflict or many antagonists so it's never stressful. It's something to play if you just want to be happy and relaxed and can be picked up quickly when you have a little free time (no super long loading screens, don't have to play with a mouse, and don't need a super great computer to run). Plus, you can save the game at literally ANY point, which is always super nice. All in all, I highly recommend this because its absolutely so cute, it can be replayed an endless amount of times with all the different choices you get, and it's also free, so why not? But, you know, I would definitely get this even if it wasn't free.
	Happy gaming!<3

130327880.review:
If you like Visual Novels and Dating Sims, this game is in my mind a must have and probably the best one there is.

I spotted this game by chance one day and it caught my interest, especially with the basegame being free, so I tried it out. And it instantly had me completely hooked that I ended up playing it over and over.
Because there are so many possibilities in how you can play the game and what kind of routes you do in what order, with so much customisation that it's almost insane. I have never seen a Dating Sim where you could actually create yourself or any kind of OC you want to such a level, since all other games I had played before have some kind preexisting personality type for the MC, unlike here where the player can decide on everything, from looks, to personality, to gender, to sexuality, and how your life with Cove will go.

The characters are all so wonderful and I instantly ended up loving them. Where once again it's completely up to the player if they want to befriend them all or not. They are fun to interact with, have heartfelt backstories to explore, and are just such loving people that it makes you feel all warm inside.
The way the game is made is so well done as well. It's such a heartwarming story where you get to grow up over the course of the story and decide on the MCs development and get to see how your past actions have influence on the later steps in game. [spoiler]Like when letting Cove in Step 1 buy you a keychain, you can later on use it in Step 3 for your phone and he will recognise it. Or how he will in both Step 2 and Step 3 gift you your favourite flower if you tell him about it in Step 1.[/spoiler] It is clear just how much love has been put into this game by the developers. Where the same can be said about all the DLC, which are worth every single last cent.
Also another thing worth mentioning, which many might also agree on; as an autistic, queer person it really made me feel so deeply loved with how much everyone in the game is accepting of it all and even encouraging about it. The same is also the case with any body types, where everyone is so loving about it. Everyone in the cast is always ready to encourage you for being yourself and openly loves you for being who you are.

All in all I love this game so much and can only keep on recommending it to everyone there is. Same as I can hardly wait when the last DLC comes out and when Our Life 2 also releases.

130230985.review:
[Fernweh]

[[Fernweh translates as “farsickness” and refers to “feeling homesick for a place you've never been or could never go."]]

TLDR;
For being a FREE base game with extremely reasonably priced DLC additions, this game is a MUST for any sappy hopeless romantics out there. I so heavily recommend this game it's not even funny.

I am not kidding when I say this game was transformative for me. As cliché as it may sound, this game changed my view on parts of my life, and it helped heal wounds I didn't even realize I had.

On a more direct note, this game had an excellent illusion of choice for my first run through. Every choice felt like it had an impact, and I held onto each moment like my life depended on it. The amount of description choices to fill out your character were superb, and extremely inclusive, even though I wish they came back up more often. Subsequent playthroughs made it easy to see through the cracks, to see that there wasn't really many choices (or at least, none I was willing to make), but that doesn't soil the initial experience. The theatre of the mind was also strong, supported by solid writing and relatable material. Cove Holden is a solidly written main character, and feels enough like a standalone person from the MC to be all the more endearing, regardless of the routes you take. The supporting characters are nothing to scoff at either - all of them are equally interesting, caring, and well thought out.

The story beats struck a chord with me and had me sobbing. Often. It's a more personal reaction based on my past experiences, but that feeling made this game all the more memorable. I will hold onto the memory of this game for possibly the rest of my life. Unironically, this game reminded me that I love the idea of love, and I love the idea of having someone in my life whose presence every day is as certain as the sun rising.

I have never felt the feeling of "Fernweh" so intensely as I did playing this game. The longing to live the simple childhood of growing up loving your best friend is something I can obviously never achieve. I will never get my childhood back, let alone in such a carefree and loving place, surrounded by so much unconditional love. And that feeling is so precious. Something I wouldn't trade for the world. There is something profound about how this game played out for me, and I can only hope others can experience even half of what I got to cherish.

Let's be real, I processed more emotional trauma because of playing through this game than in the several years I've been in therapy haha.

Even as life takes more steps forward, I know I can always return to Sunset Bird and to our lovely ocean boy. New beginnings aren't as scary when I know I always have a place to return to.

130228820.review: Honestly one of the best games I've ever played. Every single character has such depth that almost feels real to me at certain points. The art style is incredibly pleasing and I often find myself looking at the backgrounds. There is also ample LGBTQ+ representation in the games, from lesbian moms to transgender characters. The MC can even be trans or non-binary! It is also so exciting to have a character on the Autism Spectrum being the game's focal point. Cove is the first autistic character in a video game that I've come across and as someone with Autism, it makes me feel super giddy! This is a wonderful, feel-good kind of game that I'd recommend to anyone who loves visual novels and building relationships with characters.

130020034.review:
This is one of the best pieces of media of any form I've ever experienced in my life, and also one of the most affirming. I've played games that e.g. let you pick pronouns before, but to see every aspect of my identity (and behavior and sense of humor for that matter - heck, even social anxiety) represented as selectable options like it's the most common thing in the world is just... extraordinary. Many other reviews talk about the romance Our Life offers, but that romance is entirely optional; in my opinion this game is the single best fictional example of aromanticism out there, and I've been through [i]all[/i] the popular aro/ace fiction.

Our Life: Beginnings & Always offers an intensely captivating narrative that draws you in instantly and completely. The nostalgic elements hit perfectly for me since the characters would've been born the same year I was. I'm not normally one for visual novels/text-focused games, but Our Life does [b][i]everything[/i][/b] right. The art and music are both excellent in addition to the storytelling. Oh, and the DLC are excellently priced too for how many hours of gameplay and how much depth they add.

I would kill to have spent my real childhood growing up with Cove Holden in Sunset Bird. Our Life is really that enthralling.

128636413.review:
I am on my second play through and plan on choosing Derek to see what happens. My first run through we only could choose Cove but I still LOVED the game.  It is a fun "choose your adventure" with choices that affect how Cove acts around you and where the story goes/what choices are available to you in the future.  The quicker you go to romance (which the first time I started out already crushing on Cove), you have ALOT of choices romantically in teen and adult phase. 

I am starting second go round as friends with Cove in both kid and teen so I can like Derek later and see what happens!

Even if they dont (but especially if they do) as a romantic choice, I will play through again just to see what other options I can get!!

The story is simple and enjoyable with lots of choices to really make your character different every time and also to choose new character traits each time.  

I would recommend if you like visual novel games to go through this one and buy it.  

Its truly enjoyable time you won't regret and you can make it a friend story or a romantic story or something in-between (even a break up if you want).

The characters don't say alot and there is alot of reading.  IF you don't like reading, I would shy away from this because the characters don't narrate much.  If you do love reading, the little character responses and quips along the way are a nice enhancement to your reading the story.

I hope they continue to update with other choices in the near future to keep interest in this Visual Novel Game.

128525718.review: I could absolutely write an essay about this game, but I'll try to be brief - the FREE, BASE game allows you so much freedom in how you want things with Cove to play out. Want to fall in love at first sight and get together at the first opportunity? You can do that. Want to NEVER fall in love, just be good friends for life? Right on. Want a more realistic, natural progression from strangers to friends to wanting to be more to just, well, more? I can speak from experience for that last example - it's doable and it's SATISFYING. The amount of influence you have on Cove and your relationship with him is AMAZING. This game has SO MUCH replay value, but even if you want a single run, it's about 10 hours assuming you don't skip anything. That's 10+ hours of FREE content, that YOU have crafted to your liking. Add in that there's relatively cheap DLC that practically doubles the length of the game for people (like me) wanting even more, and this game is absolutely worth it. Try the free game and if you love it half as much as I did, it's probably worth getting the DLC too.

128111126.review: This game is absolutely gorgeous. I just finished my first playthrough and immediately started a new save file! I downloaded the Step 1, 2, and 3 expansion packs and I'm super excited to play with all of my new choices and memories! The LGBTQ+ representation is amazing and they give you a TON of choices for gender expression and sexuality. Cove is such a layered character with complex emotions and reactions, and it makes it feel like your choices really really matter. Sometimes the romantic lead in other dating sims can feel a little shallow or like they'll fall in love with you no matter how you interact with them, but this game is entirely different. You can even choose to not get together with him and just be friends if you want! I haven't done that myself, but it's nice that you have the option. The settings for how Cove interacts with you are also an amazing touch. I love that you can change how much initiative he takes in interacting with you. My first playthrough I chose medium because I wanted to be the one to initiate most things, but he still initiated a little. I'm going to try high initiative in my current playthrough. So excited! Overall a fantastic game. I can't believe the base game is free! Honestly a super smart choice because I loved the game enough from trying it that buying the DLC is completely worth it. Thank you for such an amazing game! I look forward to playing any future games you put out. Keep creating <3

127080705.review: Our life: Beginnings & Always is a wonderful visual novel that you can play through over and over again, choosing different options each time as you decide what type of person your character is. Are you shy or outgoing, kind or mean, blunt or subtle and so on. Whether you decide to be best friends with Cove, the boy whom you meet when you're 8 or if you decide to develop a relationship with him- or, if neither option sounds appealing, remain completely indifferent to him. The base game is completely free, and for cheap prices you can buy the dlc's to get heaps of more content to read. Having played hundreds of hours in this game, I cannot recommend it enough. A lovely game for anyone who loves visual novels.

Truly a heart-warming and cosy game that can and should be enjoyed by everyone! The devs are incredible and made the game super inclusive to anyone who wishes to play with all their custom settings for the MC, I haven't seen anything quite like it in the Visual Novel game scene! 

This game makes you feel warm and fuzzy with its wholesome moments that are accompanied by a homey and relaxing soundtrack. However, it also has its more melancholy and sombre moments that can really touch your heart and get you feeling misty-eyed! 

A lovely and unique LGBTQ+ friendly visual novel that doesn't even have to be about romance either! I highly recommend this one, its become one of my favourite games <3

126458639.review:
I can't believe I haven't written a review for this game yet. I have done a great disservice for not reviewing the MASTERPIECE that is Our Life.
Whether your a VN addict, just barely dipping your toes into VN's, or just really dont care for VN's, Our Life is a story that you shouldn't miss out on.
The icing on the cake is the subtle changes to your MC that really put you as a person into the story. I have played through the main story so many times, each time a little different, but each time myself. As a nonbinary human being, it made me so happy to see the pronoun selection, to allow myself to begin as a child who slowly discovered who I was as a person. Every little detail and interaction in this game is fantastic, and every one should give it a shot!

125621138.review:
Happy anniversary, Our Life! Though I'd heard of the game before, I only played a few months ago, starting a save file with my girlfriend... then I ended up so addicted to it that I stayed up til 2-3 am after work playing it. Then when I finished the DLC, I stayed up til 3 yet again to write Cove/MC fanfic haha <3 

 As a VN writer and longtime gamer, Our Life is one of the best visual novels I've ever had the pleasure of playing. It's so fun and never gets old despite how many times you replay. (The variations and callbacks are insane btw, kudos to the GB Patch team for that!) 

 It's so wholesome and lighthearted. The jokes never failed to make me laugh (I loved teasing Cliff and Cove). And the hurt/comfort moments were handled so excellently. The Reflections DLC moment got me bawling so hard. The realism and depth of these characters are amazing. 

 Whoever said the perfect man doesn't exist has never met Cove Holden. (And this is where I took a mini break to cry because I miss him so much.) Getting to know him was such a precious, irreplaceable experience. He's a wonderful friend and playing the platonic route was fun, but honestly? He's one of my Top Tier LIs of all time. Sweet, stubborn, and maybe a little bit spoiled (who can say no to him??), Cove is so easy to love. His struggles in dealing with change is so relatable. The way he can be /our constant/ in a life that's ever changing is so beautiful. I can't wait to replay the game and love Cove all over again!! 

 Derek was fricking amazing too. He's such hardworking thoughtful guy with issues that cut deep (I vibed with having a fam that's very dependent on you and struggling to figure out your career). 

 I'M SO EXCITED FOR BAXTER WHO I [lowkey sp0iler alert] ACCIDENTALLY GOT AT THE SOIREE IN STEP 2 BY A STROKE OF FATE LMAO!!! [end sp0iler]

Like I said, the supporting cast was so fun and comforting too. Ma and Mom are lovely, and I adore Kyra and Cliff so much. Elizabeth really felt like an older sibling, and I love the Filipino rep <3 

 All in all, it broke my heart to say goodbye to Sunset Bird, especially since real life changed so drastically, so similarly to the end of step 3. But Cove was always there. Every, "See you tomorrow" came true (especially at the butt crack of dawn, oh Cove). There are no words to accurately describe how returning to Sunset Bird feels so comforting, how being surrounded by all these loving and lovable characters felt like family, and how seeing Cove again feels like home, the way our MC is home to him. 

 Thank you so much, GB Patch. I genuinely can't wait to see more from the Our Life Cinematic Universe 🥺 💜​

125474252.review: This is by far the best dating sim I have ever played. The story is beautiful and all of the characters feel like real people who develop naturally over the course of the four sections of the game. The dialogue is both fun and accurate to how real people talk. The MC's relationships with their mothers, sister, and especially Cove are all extremely well developed no matter which path you choose. You can do indifferent to lovers, friends to lovers, or mutual pining in your relationship with Cove, all of which are fun routes to play. I highly recommend going the friends to lovers route because that felt the most satisfying for me, especially waiting until the very end for the confession, but I am a sucker for slow burns. I also highly recommend the DLCs for this game because they all add exciting and fun new stories that show even more sides of the wonderful characters, like Cove's parents and the MC's high school friends. This game is very relaxing and gave me all sorts of fluffy feelings and I don't think any other dating sim will ever match this experience.

125445825.review: I love the game and the story line. There wasn't a moment where I didn't enjoy the play through. The fact that the game incorporates many things as well as LGBTQ options is what makes it even better. I honestly have to force myself to stop playing it to get some rest because it's that good. This game to me is comfort in the good and amazing kind of way. Although three achievements were hard for me to accomplish but I did (although it physically hurt me to say the least given that Cove Holden is such an amazing guy; I mean play all three steps with disinterest was too much for my heart! I had to stop myself from getting severe depression but I got better by playing it all over again lmao!) But all in all this is an amazing game where i would stop recommending it especially with the new Derek content which makes it all even better!
